title: Add option to hide the Dock icon on OSX
body: (TPD) Sparkleshare runs perfectly well without the need for a dock icon.
(TPD) Having one just adds clutter as all functionality can be found in the menu icon.
(TPD) other applications (e.g.
(TPD) Davmail) add an option to hide it, too.
(TP) duplicate of #30.
(FP) Dropbox, LaunchBar, Shimo, nexTab, Video Steam Server, f.lux are all running on my mac just fine without Dock icon.

(FP) reading through the developers comments, I realize that he believes that a Dock icon is necessary, but I would argue that Dropbox's success is evidence that his assumption about Mac user expectations is incorrect.
CORRECTION: The developer believes that the Icon and Alt-Tab behaviour are very important to usability when SparkleShare's dialog windows are open.
@ryanerwin you are twisting my words.
i never said anything like that.
(TP) SparkleShare needs a dock icon when the setup dialog or event log are open, but OS X doesn't have official APIs available to hide the dock icon again after those windows are closed.
the apps you mention are all closed source, so i can't see how they do this.
i'm sure Dropbox would still be a success if they had a dock icon all the time.
(TP) people don't use it because it doesn't have a dock icon, but because it syncs their files in a simple way.
you're making stuff up.
the current dock icon behaviour is a compromise to not be utterly broken.
(FP) if you know someone who can make this feature happen, please let me know so we can fix this issue!
(FP) i'll be the first one to accept the patch.
You're right hbons, I didn't quite understand where you're coming from.

(TP) If you want the Dock icon (to support alt-tab) when Recent changes / Add Hosted Project / About Sparkle Share dialogs are active, but not when the only the Menubar is running, that does sound like the best of both worlds.
(TP) i think that if you separate SparkleShare into two programs, one for the Dock Icon/Dialogs and one for the Menubar/Background process, it would work.
(TP) When any of the dialogs are activated, you simply launch the SparkleShare sub-program that includes both the Dock and the Dialog Screen.
(TP) That's sort of the model behind the Evernote and a few other Menubar icons.
(FP) @ryanerwin yes, that could be a solution, but it's easier said than done.
(TP) i'll need some help here, as it requires big changes in how SparkleShare is srtuctured.
(TP) maybe a fundraiser at bountysource.com/ could work?

title: fix for #5440
body: (TPD) This fixes situation where rendering template to string sets `rendered_format` to the format rendered there.

(TPD) This is ok to have consistent formats rendered in partials, but it breaks on next renders if format is explicitly set or on last render where default format does not necessarily need to be the format of first rendered template.
cc @josevalim

(TP) @josevalim ok, so only this line need to be left when I rebased to newest 3-2-stable (I thought I did it, but apparently not ;) ): https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/5480/files#L0R103 Does it look good now?

(FP) This looks a bit weird and frankly speaking I have a gut feeling that the entire thing could be refactored to be more nice in general (starting with the usage in renderers), but probably this is not safe just before rc.
(FP) Also, do we need to merge it also with master?
(FP) Yes, let's just move the logic to `_render_template` and it looks perfect now.
:+1: for merging it on 3-2-stable and master.
(FP) Overall, I actually don't think this looks weird.
Rails 3-2-stable added the possibility of passing :formats along with `render` where previously you had to pass `render :template => "foo.html"`.
(FP) `.html` was handled inside the (REsolve)r which didn't allow the format to leak but could cause weird results (like the formats being :xml and you rendering a :html file).
(FP) i think current behavior and logic is better.
(FP) > Overall, I actually don't think this looks weird.
(FP) Ok, I will need to look at the entire code again later.
Should I push it also to master?
@drogus yeah, we should apply this on master
I've ported to master
@spastorino thanks!

title: [patch] Add :full_message option to validations
body: *Imported from Lighthouse.

(TPD) * Original ticket at: http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/3768
created by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2011-04-09 22:41:48 UTC

Follows a patch to add a full_message option to validations.

(TPD) Currently Rails don't allow full control over validation messages without making use of I18n and even that solution is overkill when you only need to have full control over a validation message.

(TPD) This patch allow validations to be written as:

  validates_presence_of :name, :full_message => 'Please, specify your full name.'
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(FP) *
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-01-21 20:17:53 UTC

There is no documentation nor test files in the patch because I need some help about how to write them.

(FP) I've asked for instructions in the topic below but got no answer yet:
http://groups.google.com/group/rubyonrails-core/msg/041076c49fcaccac

Here is an extract:

-----
I don't know how to proceed with documentation, since it is not very DRY...

Should I send a description to appreciation and then copy and paste it on every validation method?
If so, would the following description be ok?

(TP) "Configuration options:
* <tt>message</tt> - A custom error message (default is: "can't be blank").

(TP) <tt>full_message</tt> can
be specified instead, in which case the humanized attribute name won't be prepended to the message.
(FN) You have to choose between either <tt>message</tt> or <tt>full_message</tt>, not both.

(FN) If that happens,
<tt>full_message</tt> takes precedence.

(FN) ..."

The only difference between validations would be the default...
Regarding test writing, I would also ask for some guidance on it.
(FP) I've noted that not all options are tested on each validation respective test.

So, I would like to know if I should add a test on with_validations_test.rb,
add a new test file or add a new test for every validation class.
Please, how should I proceed?

(FP) ---

Could you help me with documentation and test instructions?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(TP) *
Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-24 07:33:08 UTC

Hey mate, if you need help to get it documented and tests, please ask in the mailing list.
(TP) The patch needs to be (IMPROVE)d in a sense that ErrorMessage should behave like a string, so self.errors[:attribute] always return strings and not mixed objects.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(FP)*
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-24 10:30:20 UTC

Valim, I have first tried the list, as you can see in the link I've posted in my first comment, but I didn't get any help there.
I had already discussed the issue you are talking about on the list.
(FP) The problem is that I can't extend an String in a way that makes sense.
(FP) I first tried ErrorMessage to extend String, but it didn't work as I was expecting...
The mixed object was the only thing I could think of for not breaking API compatibility.
(FP) For instance, if self.errors[:attribute] always return a string, how errors.full_messages would know if it has to include a prefix or not?
(FP) If it returns an ErrorMessage object, it would break the API and possible a lot of plugins.
(TP) The solution I proposed, although not ideal, is less invasive to current API.
(TP) The correct way to do this in my opinion is to change the API so that errors[:attribute] would return an ErrorMessage object instead of a String, but that would be a big change.
(FP) I could write such patch but I doubt it would be accepted as the core team doesn't seem to be interested in such a ":full_message" feature...
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(TP) *
Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-24 10:34:26 UTC

Something like this would work:

  class ErrorMessage < String
    def initialize(message, full_message=false)
      @full_message = full_message
      super(message)
    end

    def full_message!
&& message.full_message?

array << message
    else
      # what we do today
    end
  end

I cannot see any drawbacks in this solution.
(FP) Or am I missing something?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-24 14:33:53 UTC

You're right.
(FP) When I tested subclassing String, I probably missed the message parameter in initialize.
(FP) But it is still a hack in the sense that unexpected things can happen (it would also happen with the current patch).

For instance:

  error = ErrorMessage.new('test', true)
  error.sub(/t/,'a').full_message?

(FP) # returns nil, although error.sub(/t/,'a').class == ErrorMessage

That is just an example for sub, but other methods are affected too.
(TP) But i think that is OK. At least it is better than the current patch.
(TP) I'll update the patch to subclass String instead of mixed objects and will update this ticket than.
(TP) probably tonight when I have some time... Changing Rails API would be more elegant but much more intrusive too.
Thanks!
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(FP) *
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-25 03:34:10 UTC

Here is a new patch (still lacking documentation and tests) using your suggested appraoch.
(FP) Should I post to rails core list again asking for help on documentation and tests?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(FP) *
Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-25 06:24:13 UTC

Sure, without tests and/or documentation is quite hard to understand some pieces of the code.
(FP) for example, why are you checking inside ErrorMessage if it's receiving another ErrorMessage?
What is the use case?
Why not use duck typing?
(FP) Also, I noticed that you changed all validators.
(FN) Would be better if we encapsulate the logic in one method in the EachValidator and DRY the +record.errors.add+ logic.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-25 12:00:14 UTC

I have dryied the code.
(TP) The part I have changed in all validators were necessary because it was not modular, so I couldn't change just one place.

(TP) See an example:

``` ruby
# record.errors.add(attr_name, :not_a_number, :value => raw_value, :default => options[:message])
  record.errors.add(attr_name, :not_a_number, :value => raw_value, :default => message)

# message is a new method from Validator:
def message
  return nil unless options[:full_message] || options[:message]
  @message ||= Errors::ErrorMessage.new(options)
end
```

How could I not change every validator once they extract the :message value from options?
(TP) supporting full_messages is not the only goal of this patch.
(FN) Now plugins are able to do more interesting things with the params passed to validations.

(TP) For instance:

``` ruby
  # show this specific message in blue if this validation fails
  validates_presence_of :field, :show_error => :blue
```

All options would be available through error.message[:field].first.options, and it is also possible to know if a symbol was passed to the message evaluating what os passed for :full_message or :message with error.message[:field].first.message.
(TP) Having said that, duck typing in ErrorMessage#initialize would loose the options and original message if another ErrorMessage is passed to ErrorMessage#new.

(TP) The above extract of the patch wouldn't be necessary, but it is there just for performance concerns:

``` ruby
  predicate = ErrorMessage.new(predicate) unless predicate.is_a?

(TP) ErrorMessage
  # this could be just:
  predicate = ErrorMessage.new(predicate)
```

Regarding the documentation, it would be like the text in my first comment.
(TP) I just don't know if I should add that explanation to every single validation...

(TP) The test case would be something like (I didn't test the code below):

``` ruby
  test "Validation should accept an :full_message option" do
    fm = 'You should specify your full name.'

(TP) # some setup code (validates_presence_of :name, :full_message => fm)
    assert_equals fm, errors.full_messages[:name]
  end
  # one more test for passing a symbol instead of a string to :full_message
```

Don't hesitate in asking me further doubts.
(TP) P.S: one more thing: with this change of subclassing String, now it is possible to use Array(messages) as in the original code instead of Array.wrap(messages).
(TP) I just forgot to change this back on my patch, but I'll do it on next patch.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

(TP) *
Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-25 12:15:57 UTC

Yes, you need to change all validators but if you are going to do that, it's better that they now all call the same method.
(TP) however, validators should not know about ErrorMessage, they should simple call record.errors.add which will know what to do.
(TP) Also, I don't see the point in having options inside ErrorMessage.
(TP) Don't try to embrace the world in this first patch (like adding extra options to validations), just ensure :full_message works.
(TP) It makes hard to review and hides the real intent.
(FP) After we get full_messages patch applied, we can continue from it.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-25 13:48:16 UTC

Sorry, I didn't understand.
How much dryier can this be?
(FP) All validators just call the message method from Validator (from which them all inherit from).
(FP) That method extract the message from the options.
(FP) What would suggest instead of this?
How could this be simpler than that?
(FP) And I don't get what are the advantages for not storing all validation options?
(FP) Why should this go in a separate patch?

(TP) I'm not hiding the real intent, but I do intend multiple features:
 - supporting full_messages
 - store all validation options

If I have some way to know what options were passed to some validation, I could have done a plugin without monkey patches for supporting full_messages, for instance...

(TP) This change will be specially useful for I18n plugins because they will be able to do lazy evaluation (actually re-evaluation) for instance if they decide to override full_messages_for, for instance.
(TP) The patch for supporting just the :full_message option would not be that different from what it is now.
Why do you think this is difficult to review?
(TP) I'll add all this documentation (including custom options) in the final patch.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-25 16:14:47 UTC

This is exactly the issue.
(TP) If you want to add multiple features, do them in separate patches and not in only one.
And is not only about being dry, validators should not know anything about ErrorMessage.
ErrorMessage is an ActiveModel::Errors concern, not a ActiveModel::Validators one.
(FN) Everything on the validators should be done through the errors.add interface.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-25 16:55:38 UTC

> This is exactly the issue.
(TP) If you want to add multiple features, do them in separate patches and not in only one.

(TP) I would agree if they were two completely and independent things, but i think they are too closely related in terms of implementation that I don't understand why would it be better to separate in two patches...
(TP) The final review effort will actually be higher... Splitting it in two patches would require me a lot of effort and I would just want to understand why it does compensate...
(FP) I mean, what are the disadvantages of storing the options passed to the validators alongside with the message?
I can't understand why you are insisting that validators should not know about ErrorMessage...
There is no mention to ErrorMessage in any of the validators...
(TP) The only difference is that instead of passing options[:message] to errors.add, they would pass the result of the method 'message' from their parent Validator.
(TP) If they wish to pass options[:message] instead, it will still work as before, but will not support the full_message parameter... Could you please be more specific about your concerns?

You wrote previously:

    # message is a new method from Validator:

(FN) Validator should use record.errors.add.

Comment by **Rodrigo Rosenfeld Rosas** - 2010-02-25 17:43:12 UTC

Are you suggesting me to change errors.add API to include an additional option?
(FP) I could do that, but that would be a completely different patch.
I was trying to avoid changing errors.add API.
(FP) But there is a problem with this appraoch.

(FP) For each validator it would be necessary to change the errors.add line to something like:

``` ruby
# record.errors.add(attr_name, :not_a_number, :value => raw_value, :default => options[:message])
  record.errors.add(attr_name, :not_a_number, :value => raw_value, :default => options[:full_message] || options[:message], :full_message => options.has_key?

(:full_message)
# or
  record.errors.add(attr_name, :not_a_number, :value => raw_value, :default => message, :full_message => options.has_key?

(:full_message) # with message returning options[:full_message] || options[:message]
```

This seems much uglier to me.
What do you think?
(TP) But I still think that the current proposed patch would be much more complete and benefic than just adding a :full_message option, don't you think?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

Comment by **José Valim** - 2010-02-25 20:42:37 UTC

Why changing each validator is a problem?

(TP) We are changing it anyway, we just need a method that does it for us:

    def add_error(record, attribute, message, extra_options = {})
      record.errors.add(attribute, message, { :message => message, :full_message => full_message }.merge(extra_options))
    end

Doing it with errors.add allows me to use :full_message in any other place in my code, without requiring knowledge of a class called ErrorMessage, which should be an implementation detail.

title: IE8 doesn't follow redirect after login
body: Hi, I'm having trouble with a flash uploader in rails305, devise121 and IE8.

When I examine the session cookie directly after the login, I see:

{"warden.user.user.key"=>["User", [BSON::ObjectId('4d8db684170048b902000002')], "$2a$10$uyPZznH83nqhJ7CgsHFy5O"], "warden.user.user.session"=>{"last_request_at"=>2011-04-03 14:24:33 UTC}, "flash"=>{:notice=>"Signed in successfully.

"}, "session_id"=>"75ba51b5d9c6119468d4ea7f4a0df7d9"}

This doesn't contain the csrf_token.
(FPD) googling, I found issues with subdmomains and cookies, but this is not the case here - the connection just goes via https.

(FPD) This is the related controller action:

  def create
    reset_session
    resource = warden.authenticate!

(:scope => resource_name, :recall => "#{controller_path}#new")
    set_flash_message(:notice, :signed_in) if is_navigational_format?

sign_in(resource_name, resource)
    current_user.update_attribute(:channel, random_md5_key)
    respond_with resource, :location => redirect_location(resource_name, resource)
  end

other browsers directly show the right cookie.
I'd be very thankful for any hints on this!
--Frank
I have no idea.
(TP) Can you try the mailing list?
Maybe some people there may be aware of the issue.
(FN) Also, have you tried removing devise from the equation?
Maybe the issue is on another place.
Hi Jose, thank you for your reply!
(TP) It turns out, that this is not a specific IE problem, I just never saw it on Firefox, because it didn't use the flash fallback - I have to investigate further.
--Frank

title: Homebrew doesn't know what compiler versions ship with your version of Xcode
body:
Upon installing homebrew, I received the error:

Error: Homebrew doesn't know what compiler versions ship with your version of
Xcode.

Please file an issue with the output of `brew --config`:

It asked me to submit an issue... so here ya go.
(FPD) As a side note, I just downgraded my MacPro from 10.8 to 10.6.8 and had to use an old copy of XCode 4.1 I had saved, as Apple no longer allows downloads of XCode that support Snow Leopard.

shaheens:~ sghiassy$ brew --config
HOMEBREW_VERSION: 0.9.3
HEAD: 81f9a64060cc088a5f793890de9d99f52f577b8a
HOMEBREW_PREfix: /usr/local
HOMEBREW_CELLAR: /usr/local/Cellar
CPU: 16-core 64-bit nehalem
OS X: 10.6.8-x86_64
Xcode: 4.1
GCC-4.2: build 5666
LLVM-GCC: build 2335
Clang: 2.1 build 163
X11: 2.3.6 => /usr/X11
System Ruby: 1.8.7-249
Perl: /usr/bin/perl
Python: /usr/bin/python
Ruby: /usr/bin/ruby => /System/Library/Frameworks/Ruby.framework/Versions/1.8/usr/bin/ruby
(FN) Having the same problem, thinking this may be an issue caused by Xcode 4.5, made sure I had the new Command Line Tools installed.
(TP) @tomhut This isn't an "issue", it's just a note that your version of Xcode isn't/wasn't documented in Homebrew.
(FN) I recently added the compiler versions for Xcode 4.5; please `brew update` and you should no longer see the warning.
(TP) @sghiassy We only officially support Xcode 3.2.6 and 4.2 on Snow Leopard, but you should be fine with Xcode 4.1.
(TP) you can ignore the warning safely.

title: RDS: auto_minor_version_upgrade option does not work correctly
body:
In the file `boto/boto/rds/__init__.py`, the following line is used to set the value of the parameter `auto_minor_version_upgrade`:

```python
'AutoMinorVersionUpgrade': str(auto_minor_version_upgrade).lower() if auto_minor_version_upgrade else None,
```

If `auto_minor_version_upgrade` is set to False, then the condition evaluates to False, and the AutoMinorVersionUpgrade is set to None rather than "false," which means that the auto upgrades are enabled (the default behavior).

(TPD) The line should read:
```python
'AutoMinorVersionUpgrade': str(auto_minor_version_upgrade).lower() if not(auto_minor_version_upgrade is None) else None,
```

In the meantime, a workaround that will disable the minor upgrades is to set `auto_minor_version_upgrade='false'`
Empty

title: python: depend on x11 when installing option  with-brewed-tk

Brewed-tk requires x11 libs to be present in order to build the tkinter
library.

(TP) Ctherefore, what really needs to happen is that python needs to depend on x11 if and only if tcl-tk was build with the `--with-x11` option.
Is there a procedure for doing this automatically?

title: Allow upload_archive to accept file like objects
body:
(TPD) The entire file is never read into memory, only single
chunks are read at a time.

(FND) This greatly reduces the memory usage, but it also appears to have sped
up performance for single operation uploads.

(TPD) In testing various
archive sizes, I saw roughly 20% performance (IMPROVE)ments.

(TPD) A few notes about the changes:

* I changed `x-amz-content-length` to `Content-Length`.

(FND) From the
  docs: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/amazonglacier/latest/dev/api-common-request-headers.html
  I couldn't find any info on this header, and if a Content-Length
  is not provided, boto.connection.HTTPRequest would try to
  `str(len(body))` to calculate this.
(FND) * Sigv4 assumes the body is a string.

(TPD) I modified the payload method
  to support being passed file like objects and computing the hash
  by reading in configurable chunk sizes at a time.

(TPD) This does
  mean that the sha256 of the body is being computed twice, once for the
  x-amz-content-sha256 header needed by glacier, and once for the
  signature.

(TPD) We *could* avoid doing this twice by checking if that header
  exists when we're signing the request, and to just use
  x-amz-content-sha256, but that seems like we're crossing abstraction
  boundaries.
(FPD) however, if you guys want this, I can add it.
Empty

title: update to RabbitMQ 3.1.3. Move to standalone bundle tarball.
body: This pull request brings RabbitMQ up to the most-recently-released 3.1.3 version.
(TPD) This version was released days after 3.1.2 due to a bug in the federation plugin which has now been fixed.
(TPD) At the request of the RabbitMQ dev team this formula now targets their standalone Mac bundle which includes an Erlang release, rather than their "generic UNIX" bundle.
(FND) This is in line with the way in which e.g.
(FND) Riak is packaged and installed by homebrew.
(TPD) therefore the dependency on standalone Erlang is dropped.
(TPD) This may mean that some users who only had Erlang installed to support RabbitMQ will now have a redundant package, but it will speed the install for new users.
(TPD) This pull request also includes a configuration file change which enables MQTT, STOMP and AMQP-1.0 plugins by default (previously only the management plugins were enabled by default).
Replaces #20807 and inlines enabled_plugins as requested.
Hurrah passed Jenkins this time :-)

title: Using materials and textures with JSON loader / OBJ models
body: (TPD) Hi - I've created a model which I converted with the python script to JS, and I've successfully imported it into my scene.
(FPD) however, it's not clear to me how the associated materials are added to the mesh.
(FPD) When I try to use the materials, the model just becomes black.
(FPD) I've looked at the obj_loader file in the example files, but I can't seem to trace down how it is assigning which materials to apply to the mesh and where.
In the example, there is a callback function specified in the loader variable declaration.
That function calls createScene, and createScene creates a mesh.
(FPD) But the materials seem to just be new THREE.MeshFaceMaterial() function calls, not specific materials.
(FPD) I assume that means the .js file for the model is specifying those materials (seems to from the code), but how does it choose where to apply those materials and which to apply?
If I swap out the obj js file in the example for my own, the model is black.
Could this be some sort of scene lighting issue or something?
Or maybe an error with the way the model was exported (from Maya)?
(FPD) Would love some help with trying to get this working.
Thanks!
There is no `obj_loader` file in the `/examples` folder... ?
Do you mean `webgl_loader_json_objconverter`?

title: A get with an invalid port should wrap urllib3's LocationParseError exception with our own.
body:
(TPD) fixes this issue:

```python
>>> import requests
>>> requests.get('http://google.com:banana')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/umbrae/Envs/rdb/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 51, in get
    return request('get', url, **kwargs)
[...snip...]
  File "/Users/umbrae/Envs/rdb/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 579, in get_host
    raise LocationParseError("Failed to parse: %s")
requests.packages.urllib3.exceptions.LocationParseError: (LocationParseError(...), 'Failed to parse: Failed to parse: %s')
```

To now return a wrapped exception, which hides the use of urllib3 and is more intuitive to catch:

```python
>>> import requests
re>>> requests.get('http://google.com:banana')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "requests/api.py", line 52, in get
    return request('get', url, **kwargs)
  File "requests/api.py", line 40, in request
    return s.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)
  File "requests/sessions.py", line 208, in request
    r.send(prefetch=prefetch)
  File "requests/models.py", line 506, in send
    raise InvalidURL(e)
requests.exceptions.InvalidURL: (LocationParseError(...), 'Failed to parse: Failed to parse: google.com')
```

You're amazing: 

:cake:

title: Jekyll command to publish a draft
body: (FND) It would be great to have a command to publish a draft.
(TPD) for example if you did `jekyll publish _draft/path-to-draft.md` it would move the file into your _posts folder and date it with the current date.
(TPD) I would love to help implement the feature but I cannot seem to get jekyll to build on my machine.
When trying to build I get the following error.
(FPD) I might be totally missing something but any nudge in the right direction or quick steps to building and iterating would be great.

```(master)$ jekyll build --trace
/Users/zsiegel/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p194/gems/commander-4.1.5/lib/commander/runner.rb:365:in `block in require_program': program version required (Commander::Runner::CommandError)```


Thanks!
(FP) I was just thinking the same thing.
(FN) It does feel to me like a natural extension of the drafts feature.
Great idea!
(FN) That error is usually due to a Syntax Error.
(TP) Within your fork, run `bundle exec rake console` or, if that doesn't work, `bundle exec irb -r lib/jekyll.rb` and the error should show itself.
(FN) Commander uses a lot of metaprogramming that swallows this.
@benbalter @mattr- what do you think of this?
(TP) @parkr thanks for your help i was able to track down the issues and it seems to be building and running the tests now.
Ill try and hack around this weekend and see what I can come up with.
I like it.
When could we see some code?

:smiley:


On Thu, Aug 29, 2013 at 11:41 AM, Zac Siegel <notifications@github.com>wrote:

> @parkr <https://github.com/parkr> thanks for your help i was able to
> track down the issues and it seems to be building and running the tests
> now.
Ill try and hack around this weekend and see what I can come up with.

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/mojombo/jekyll/issues/1469#issuecomment-23504023>
> .
(FP) I've been giving this some thought, and I've actually started to open an issue several times called "deprecate drafts", but haven't gone through with it.
(TP) i think drafts as a feature encourage the wrong workflow.
(FN) The command to publish a draft should be `git merge feature-branch`.
(FN) The amazing thing about Jekyll is that it treats content as code.
(TP) It wraps your code in the same satin blanket that is GIt as geeks do with the software they use to publish that same content, and that makes a heck of a lot of sense.
(FN) After all, the content is the important part, not the platform.
(FN) Geeks care about code, and if so much as a single line is off, things break.
(FN) That's why we have great tools, and that's why applying that workflow and that philosophy to content is so powerful.
(FN) The draft feature breaks that flow.

(TP) It says hey, even though we have this amazing tooling that allows us to create parallel versions, save them, version them, expose them early on for feedback from others... lets ignore all that and invent our own system to stage content.
(FN) We don't do that with code, we shouldn't do that with text.

(TP) Here's how a draft flow should work if we want to encourage flow:

1.

`git checkout -b descriptive-name`
2.

`touch _posts/YYYY-MM-DD-descriptive-name.md`
3.

`$EDITOR _posts/YYYY-MM-DD-descriptive-name.md`
4.

`git add _posts`
5.

`git commit _posts`
6.

[a pull request if working with others]
7.

(TP) `git checkout master && git merge descriptive-name`

That process isn't for everyone, but we can build tooling to fix that.
What if `jekyll draft foo` did step 1-3.
What if `jekyll publish foo` did steps 4-7.
What if we encouraged our users to use an established, but significantly more evolved workflow, rather than building our own from scratch.
**Caveat:** This assumes you're using git, which up until now, Jekyll does not.
(FP)We'd either want to make that assumption, or have a non-git fallback to the existing workflow.
(TP) i think that wouldn't enable the 'browse your drafts, and see which you feel like developing a bit more' kind of workflow which it currently encourages.
(TP) i think that's kind of what it's built around.
@benbalter Great thoughts.
(FP) seems so simple now that you mention it.

:smiley:

With Ben's example, you'd have a different feature branch for each draft.
Browsing your drafts becomes a simple `git branch`.

@FellowMD Would that
address your workflow issues?
If I had to switch one by one between drafts that would ruin the feature for me.
(TP) There's something about having them all displayed next to each other that helps you realize which one should see the light of day next.

(FN) Like this: http://obtvse.herokuapp.com/admin
(username:username, password:password)
Whoa whoa hold your :horse:!
(FN) We can't assume everyone uses Git (as Ben mentioned) and I'd feel really uncomfortable about integrating git with Jekyll so tightly.
(TP) It's enforcing a workflow that isn't flexible – what if I work in a different way?
(TP) I'll submit a PR  to modify the workflow or never use this feature.
(FP) Integrating git is a can of worms I don't want to open.
(TP) All we want is an automated way to move a file from `_drafts` to `_posts` and to give it that moment's date.
(TP) Doing anything more is locking us and our users into a certain way of working and this project doesn't seem to be about that at all.
(TP) The idea is brilliant and the workflow certainly works for some, but I don't think it's within the domain of Jekyll to enforce this.
(FN) It's more in the domain of Octopress than Jekyll.
(TP) I kind of agree with Parker.
(FN) I was thinking about a basic command that would move and date the draft appropriately.
(TP) Obviously I could do this with shell scripting or other methods on my local machine but I thought it might be a nice extension to the drafts functionality.

Within the git workflow Ben mentioned I could see the following…

- git branch my-draft-branch
- jekyll publish _drafts/path-to-draft.md
- git commit & Push
Nobody ever said we would be integrating Git in to Jekyll or enforcing a workflow.
(FP) We're just having a discussion about workflows.
Let's calm down, shall we?

(FP) :smiley: 

Do i think using git to manage your workflow makes sense?
(TP) Sure I do, so I'll make it my workflow and not force it on any one else.
Ultimately, Jekyll's workflow is based around having a particular directory structure and putting things in the appropriate buckets in that structure.
That's it.
(TP) whether or not we have helpers for that in Jekyll core is a discussion we need to have.

> whether or not we have helpers for that in Jekyll core is a discussion we need to have

:+1:

(TP) @parkr agree with everything you're saying, and that's why I caveated that any tooling can't exclusively assume git, but one word of caution:

>  It's enforcing a workflow that isn't flexible... locking us and our users into a certain way of working

(setting aside the fact that regardless of implementation a `draft` command would be opt in and in no way exclusive),  that's exactly what we're doing here by adding this command.
There's going to be a workflow behind it either way.
(FP) I'm just asking if we're building towards the best workflow.
Tooling and defaults are more powerful than you think.
(FN) We're building Jekyll around a certain workflow as is.
(FN) That workflow involves a `_drafts` folder, and moving files around.

(FN) If I'm a new user and I go to docs and ask "what's the best way to draft a Jekyll post", and it says, don't bother with anything that's established, we've got our own way of doing things... that's setting forward a particular workflow.
(FN) A `draft` command would be additional tooling and would go a long way to set a standard workflow in a way that hasn't been done to date...

(TP) I was simply asking not if that's a viable workflow, or lowest-common-denominator workflow, but if that's the best workflow that we can imagine, and if that's what we want to be making the default.

(TP) Yes, we can't assume Git (although I'd argue 80%+ of the time that's how Jekyll's managed) , but I'd rather build against the ideal workflow, and fall back when we have to, not settle for second best because it's what we've done in the past.
> I've been giving this some thought, and I've actually started to open an issue several times called "deprecate drafts", but haven't gone through with it.
(FP)i think drafts as a feature encourage the wrong workflow.
(FP) I agree 100 %.
Git has already everything.
(FN) Jekyll’s draft feature is build for one-man-blogs of day dreamers who start 100 posts and never finish them.
It’s not really multi-user ready.
BTW, the draft feature was forced [8 months ago](#769) by @scribu, the Wordpress guy.
(FP) It’s a implementation of the Wordpress staging workflow, I always hated.
(FP) How many people really use this feature since it’s introduced?
(FP) The fact it’s for posts only just shows how unnecessary draft is.
(TP) Look at Jekyll’s documentation.
It’s built with pages, not posts.
(FP) Different contributors start new pages, make pull requests, get things done.
There are ~~drafts~~ git branches for *every* type of page.
(TP) It works without draft.
> BTW, the draft feature was forced 8 months ago by @scribu, the Wordpress guy.
I don't remember strong-arming anyone to commit the drafts feature.
Please don't distort history.
> I don't remember strong-arming anyone to commit the drafts feature.
Please don't distort history.
(FP) @scribu I mean you had implemented the whole feature.
Please don’t split hairs.
(TP) If I look at the Jekyll powered blogs of the *6 participants* in #769 I can’t see *nobody* who actually uses the draft feature.
@scribu, @FellowMD, @zsiegel: What is your experience with drafts?
(FP) * Did you used the draft feature since v1.0.0?
(FP) * How many percent of your blog posts since v1.0.0 was born in drafts?
* Do you know *active* Jekyll only bloggers who periodically use the draft feature?
> If I look at the Jekyll powered blogs of the 6 participants in #769 I can’t see nobody who actually uses the draft feature.
How exactly do you expect to _see_ them using the feature?
> Did you used the draft feature since v1.0.0?
Yes.
> How many percent of your blog posts since v1.0.0 was born in drafts?
> Do you know active Jekyll only bloggers who periodically use the draft feature?
I don't know any Jekyll only bloggers; sorry.
> The fact it’s for posts only just shows how unnecessary draft is.
(TP) Look at Jekyll’s documentation.
It’s built with pages, not posts.
(TP) Different contributors start new pages, make pull requests, get things done.
There are drafts git branches for every type of page.
(TP) It works without draft.
(FP) It sounds like you find the whole posts feature of Jekyll unnecessary, in which case complaining about drafts is just trolling.
(TP) @mojombo wanted a native drafts feature at the time.
(TP) Maybe he's changed his mind, but I haven't heard from him in a month or so.
(FN) I really like our drafts feature as it is and don't see a reason to deprecate it.
(TP) I'd be happy to add the alternative git-only workflow (using solely posts) to the docs under "working with drafts".

@benbalter the biggest reasons I don't like the workflow you proposed are (1) the overhead of modifying the publish date of a post that is a WIP for more than a day is annoying; (2) no way to preview the PR on GH Pages.
The `_drafts` workflow doesn't cover these either but the cost of moving my drafts to branches is too high if it doesn't offer something my current workflow doesn't.
> How exactly do you expect to see them using the feature?
(FN) I search in their public blogs source for `_drafts` folder.
Example: https://github.com/mojombo/mojombo.github.io.
I see no  `_drafts` folder here.

(TP) That's because it's ignored: https://github.com/mojombo/mojombo.github.io/blob/master/.gitignore#L1

I also ignore it for my own blog.

(TP) Granted, I also have two little bash scripts, so my workflow looks like this:

```
./bin/new-draft 'Some Title'  # creates _drafts/some-title.md and opens vim
...
./bin/publish _drafts/some-title.md
```

Without these little utilities, I can understand why drafts might seem unnecessary.
That's what this ticket is trying to address.
> BTW, the draft feature was forced 8 months ago by @scribu, the Wordpress guy.
(FP) @scribu you and I have worked together before on WP unit tests, among other things.
Please know, that I in no way intended to imply any impropriety on your part.
(FP) :heart: that we find ourselves working on such diverse projects together yet again.

:smile:

>  How many people really use this feature since it’s introduced?
[Too many to deprecate it](https://github.com/search?l=markdown&q=path%3A_drafts&ref=advsearch&type=Code), which is why I never open the issue.
I'm not saying we should get rid of drafts.
We can't at this point.

(TP) My argument is that if we're going to be building *new* tooling around a feature, I'd love the feature to fit into a bigger vision, rather than just bolting on things because they make sense after we did something last week.
(TP) If we're going to invest the time in tooling to reduce a pain point, lets use it as an opportunity to make it easier to do the right thing, not easier to do what is arguably a janky work around.
> Granted, I also have two little bash scripts...
(FP) Without these little utilities, I can understand why drafts might seem unnecessary.
That's what this ticket is trying to address.
Spot on.
The feature as it is now lacks tooling.
(FP) i think we can all assume that as a given.

(TP) > the overhead of modifying the publish date of a post that is a WIP for more than a day is annoying; 

This issue is designed to fix just that.

(TP) The discussion is whether we should build towards a `_drafts`-bespoke workflow, or encourage even super-basic Git flow (think analogous to GitHub edit-fork-PR web interface but for Jekyll command line).

> The _drafts workflow doesn't cover these either but the cost of moving my drafts to branches is too high...

Moving meaning placing each current draft in a branch?
(FP) Totally agree, but I'd argue you're an edge case, or even if not, the feature's only been around since 1.0.
> if it doesn't offer something my current workflow doesn't.
(TP) ...which is why I'm proposing tooling that uses the branch workflow if the site is versioned in Git, (otherWISE) falling back to the `_drafts` workflow.
(FP) Encourage the best practice, support the rest.
Hey @benbalter!
> ...which is why I'm proposing tooling that uses the branch workflow if the site is versioned in Git, (otherWISE) falling back to the _drafts workflow.
(FN) And you'd also have to account for the case where the site is versioned in Git, but `_drafts` is ignored.

(TP) As a more general note, you seem to be saying two slightly contradictory things:

* let's figure out the best workflow.
(TP) * let's support the branch-based workflow, because it's the best.
Pick one.
Nevermind that last note.

(TP) I re-read the whole thread and the gist seems to be:

Let's add tooling for the branch-based workflow, because it's better; but, since we can't get rid of _drafts, let's support that too.
I understand your workflow.
(TP) You don’t want to share your drafts with public, until they are ready to publish as a regular post.
So it’s not only technical decision but also a psychological one.
(TP) This method works for one-man blogs only.
(TP) If you want to build a magazine with reporters, editors and so on, it doesn’t really work anymore.
(FN) The git based workflow scales for every team size.
(FN) If you start a new branch `article` and write `_posts/2013-09-11-article.md`, you have a deadline that kicks your ass to finish the post in time.
(TP) Then you can send your branch to your chief editor, she would merge it in the `develop` branch and see the big picture.
(TP) The git is made for team work.
(TP) I hope the draft feature supports you by writing.
>  You don’t want to share your drafts with public, until they are ready to publish as a regular post.
Which to clarify, you don't have to do with a branch-based workflow either.
(TP) just don't push the branch.
(FP) Also, having a bunch of drafts just sitting on my hard drive and not backed up anywhere would scare the :shit: out of me.
To the :cloud:!
The assumption is that git branches and _drafts are mutually exclusive.
But what's wrong with opening a pull request against a file in the `_drafts` folder (assuming it's not in .gitignore)?
> Which to clarify, you don't have to do with a branch-based workflow either.
just don't push the branch.

> 
> Also, having a bunch of drafts just sitting on my hard drive and not backed up anywhere would scare the :shit: out of me.
To the :cloud:!
(FP) @benbalter I agree again.
(FP) The current draft feature is just a little helper.
The branch-based workflow is the most promising code writing style of today’s world.
> But what's wrong with opening a pull request against a file in the _drafts folder (assuming it's not in .gitignore)?
Totally valid question.

(TP) 1) it's not proper [git-flow](http://scottchacon.com/2011/08/31/github-flow.html) (`master` is live, branches as development), and 2) two users collaborating on the same repository can't submit a pull request from `master` back onto `master`, you can't do line-by-line review or discuss a commit to master, or receive notifications about the commit... the idea is you'd want the initial draft prior to publishing to be the pull request, not subsequent revisions... you don't want a pull request to correct a typo on a draft just because it's already hit master.
(TP) And please remember the possible assets for your drafts: images, videos, archives, etc.
(FN) The draft feature can not handle these files.
Ok, those are valid points.
How does Octopress handle drafts again?
> How does Octopress handle drafts again?

(FN) They use `published: false` (which Jekyll also recognizes as an alternative drafts workflow) which from a flow standpoint is essentially the same as `_drafts` (using a YAML flag rather than a file path flag to determine published status).
I don't know what to say.
(TP) On the one hand, `_drafts` works best for single-author blogs (even without assets).
(TP) On the other hand, branches work best for more serious publishing.
(TP) In both cases, the tooling doesn't really need to be shipped with Jekyll, so maybe it would be best to leave it for third-parties, for now.
(FN) Maybe @benbalter will write an extension that will knock our socks off.
(FN) From a single author standpoint, it's really helpful to have many draft posts percolating in the background.
I personally have my drafts on my Dropbox, with a symlink of _drafts->~/Dropbox/drafts.
(TP) Professional writers may have one article they work on until it's done, but amateur single authors aren't sure what we want to publish until we've written it.
Kicking my ass to meet a deadline isn't necessary.
(TP) From what I can see, the branch based workflow flat out breaks the ability to see all these evolving posts next to each other and see the bigger picture.
Let me know if I'm wrong there.

(TP) It does seem there's a bit of tension between the ideal workflows of small and large blogs, but the project seemed to me to be weighted a bit toward the small blogger than the large blog even before I started using it

> 2) two users collaborating on the same repository can't submit a pull request from master back onto master, you can't do line-by-line review or discuss a commit to master, or receive notifications about the commit... the idea is you'd want the initial draft prior to publishing to be the pull request, not subsequent revisions... you don't want a pull request to correct a typo on a draft just because it's already hit master.
(FP) i think I phrased the question wrong.
(TP) There's nothing stopping you from creating the draft in the branch.
(TP) And whether you start off in the `_drafts` folder or in `_posts`, when merging into master, you will most likely need to rename the file.
(FN) So, I still think that the `_drafts` folder could be useful for both single-author and multi-author blogs.
> From what I can see, the branch based workflow flat out breaks the ability to see all these evolving posts next to each other and see the bigger picture.
Let me know if I'm wrong there.
You are correct.

title: Speed up xbmc ui nav by change loaders use StopAsync(true)
body: (FPD) currently, each time when nav win changed the path, the bg info loader has to wait all workers stopped and block ui.
(FPD) if the worker is working on a slow task, e.g.
(FPD) list a zip file or on slow link, this will make the ui looks 'lock'.
(TPD) This PR changed the StopAsync method of bg loader, make it support finish (save) current work asap, before the working workers finish their half work.

(TP) I haven't reviewed, but one thing to keep in mind is that there's only one
worker thread nowadays, so much of the logic can be simplified.

(TP)Further, we
need the ability to run at least 2 loops over the items rather than just
one.
(FN) Doing so will speed up thumb setting etc.

On Mar 21, 2013 8:30 PM, "ulion" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> currently, each time when nav win changed the path, the bg info loader has
> to wait all workers stopped and block ui.

if the worker is working on a
> slow task, e.g.

list a zip file or on slow link, this will make the ui
> looks 'lock'.

> This PR changed the StopAsync method of bg loader, make it support finish
> (save) current work asap, before the working workers finish their half work.

(TP) > ------------------------------
> you can merge this Pull Request by running
>
>   git pull https://github.com/ulion/xbmc fasten_ui_by_loader_stopasync
>
> Or view, comment on, or merge it at:
>
>   https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476
> Commit Summary
>
>    - Add CThread::IsCurrentThreadStopping() to check current thread
>    stopping.
>    - Add class CDBCloseGuard for auto-close database when leave scope.

>    - Add exit points for loaders' LoadItem() to speed up if thread going
>    to stop.

>    - change CBackgroundInfoLoader::StopAsync() to support finish and
>    discard left work.
>    - change CBackgroundInfoLoader::Load() to stop previous work asap.

>    - change all CBackgroundInfoLoader::StopThread() to StopAsync(true) to
>    fasten xbmc ui.

>
> File changes
>
>    - *M* xbmc/BackgroundInfoLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-0>(84)
>    - *M* xbmc/BackgroundInfoLoader.h<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-1>(9)
>    - *M* xbmc/ThumbLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-2>(2)
>    - *M* xbmc/addons/GUIWindowAddonBrowser.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-3>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/dbwrappers/Database.h<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-4>(9)
>    - *M* xbmc/dialogs/GUIDialogFileBrowser.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-5>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/MusicInfoLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-6>(23)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/MusicThumbLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-7>(5)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/windows/GUIWindowMusicNav.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-8>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/windows/GUIWindowMusicPlaylist.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-9>(12)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/windows/GUIWindowMusicPlaylistEditor.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-10>(8)
>    - *M* xbmc/music/windows/GUIWindowMusicSongs.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-11>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/pictures/GUIWindowPictures.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-12>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/pictures/PictureInfoLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-13>(11)
>    - *M* xbmc/pictures/PictureThumbLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-14>(1)
>    - *M* xbmc/programs/GUIWindowPrograms.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-15>(4)
>    - *M* xbmc/pvr/windows/GUIWindowPVRRecordings.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-16>(2)
>    - *M* xbmc/threads/Thread.h<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-17>(5)
>    - *M* xbmc/video/VideoThumbLoader.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-18>(13)
>    - *M* xbmc/video/windows/GUIWindowVideoBase.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-19>(8)
>    - *M* xbmc/video/windows/GUIWindowVideoNav.cpp<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476/files#diff-20>(4)
>
> patch Links:
>
>    - https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476.patch
>    - https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476.diff
>
>

CPictureThumbLoader, CMusicThumbLoader and CVideoThumbLoader both use one worker; 
CMusicInfoLoader use one worker; but CPictureInfoLoader still use default 5 workers according to the adv setting.
what you mean 'run at least 2 loops over items' ?
(TP) There's no need for 5 workers in picture loader.
(FN) As for 2 passes, the loaders do 2 jobs.

(FN) First they set info previously
extracted, and second they extract new information.

(FN) The first is fast, the
second slow.

(FN) No point having items at the end of then list waiting on
extraction of earlier items.

On Mar 22, 2013 12:24 AM, "ulion" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> CPictureThumbLoader, CMusicThumbLoader and CVideoThumbLoader both use one
> worker;
> CMusicInfoLoader use one worker; but CPictureInfoLoader still use default
> 5 workers according to the adv setting.

>
> what you mean 'run at least 2 loops over items' ?

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/xbmc/xbmc/pull/2476#issuecomment-15231264>
> .
got what you mean, but that's another topic.
(TP) this pr is mainly to (IMPROVE) not let xbmc main thread block and wait all workers stop between nav win switch dir.
(FP) This seems overly complicated to me for what should be a pretty simple thing, perhaps due to the multiple workers and the data sharing.
(TP) Removing the data sharing will mean you can throw worker threads away when they're no longer needed for example (autodeleting threads).
(TP) With a single worker things become simpler - no need for booleans guarding the OnLoaderStart/OnLoaderFinish and the loop drops down to a for loop.
(FN) It's then easier to see when you execute OnLoaderFinish() and when you don't.

(TP) as a common base class, the CBackgroundInfoLoader class support
multiple workers, drop down to single worker doesn't change the fact
both xbmc main thread and worker thread could call OnLoaderFinish(),
so if the xbmc main thread call OnLoaderFinish() and a worker thread
still working on some work may use resources not available after
OnLoaderFinish() is called.

that's the
SINGLE_LOCK_CHECK_THread_STOP_AND_RETURN does, prevent such failure
access.
(TP) although not all subclass loaders has such design.

(TP) i think
this is the most complex part of this PR, and I had to take care of
each such shared resources to prevent the abandon worker use them.

(TP) as the autodelete, I tried it at first, but I found the difficult part
is not how the thread be stopped and deleted, it's what the worker
still running and what the worker could doing may conflict with the
new work or operate on deallocated resources by OnLoaderFinish(), or
doing some work but finally has no way to save it (since
OnLoaderFinish already be called for that Load round, for this we'd
better return asap.)
(TP) updated to mutex protect the m_database, it could be use both by xbmc main thread and worker thread when StopAsync(true)
Are CDatabase objects not threadsafe?

(TP) i think so, I crashed without mutex protect, one thread is calling the m_database->Open, and it crashed at some point in it, found the handle is closed, and 'db' pointer seems be null, so there must be some Close call during the Open call caused this, at least there's no lock protect in Open/Close, confirmed.
(TP) rebased and fixed some crash caused between xbmc main thread and loader worker thread.

(TP) also added a commit to make the CDatabase's Open/Close operation thread-safe, which fix crash when the old worker is closing db and the new worker is open db but the new one will try to close first so caused double-close crash inside sqlite_close.

(TP) I found I did try to add lock scope to all database operations in all loaders, but I missed one condition, that's the CDBCloseGuard I used, sometime when it closing the database, it is not under the lock scope, so the crash previous I mentioned happened.
(TP) then I can fix this by let CDBCloseGuard support close with lock scope, and then we can forget the database Open/Close lock, it will be not necessary then.
(TP) @ulion can you rebase/update?
(TP) seems the BackgroundInfoLoader's thread model changed during last months, so this pr may need a bigger change to fit that.
it won't be soon.

title: select_month doesn't consider :selected option
body:
(FPD) Hi Folks,

i'm trying to use select_month helper passing :selected option to select the specific month, but the select_month method doesn't seems to be considering that option.

(FPD) ```ruby
select_month(Date.today, :field_name => :month, :selected => @month)
```

Is it to supposed to work like that?
Am t doing something wrong?
Cheers!

(TP) I've just seen that is possible to pass the date or the month as the date parameter

1º
```ruby
select_month(Date.today, :field_name => :month)
```

or

2º
```ruby
select_month(08, :field_name => :month)
```

Should i use the 2º option to (REsolve) my problem?
(FP) Is that a good way to (REsolve) that?
Cheers guys!
In your case, what is the type of @month?
Is-it a date or an integer?
@Sylvain i already tried passing a date and passing a integer representing the month, but i've got problem with both.
(TP) @rodrigopinto, Yeah, you don't need `:selected` option here.
(TP) just pass the month you want to be preselected as the first arg of `select_month` method.
(TP) i think it can be closed /cc @arunagw
Thx @nashby!
(TP) I've already found the solution, anyway thanks again!

title: change post visibility after posting
body: (FPD) I usually intend to make posts public, but forget to change from "all aspects" to "public" before posting.
(TPD) Would it be possible to change post visibility after posting?
Facebook allows this.
(FPD) :) Federation may make it harder, admittedly.
(TP) This is a privacy concern, we can't allow that because users answering to your post think their answers are secret, and if you change the visibility, they'll become public.
(FN) The implications are also very similar to editing, see #1762.
(TP) This needs to be a Loomio discussion, closing.

title: [2.2] Add possibility to change default `views` directory
body: (FND) As I said here #3427, I am submitting a way to override the path of the `views` directory for a specific bundle.

(TPD) you can just add to your configuration:

```
framework:
    templating:
        view_directories:
            AcmeDemoBundle: /Views/
```

Bug fix: no
Feature addition: yes
Backwards compatibility break: no
Symfony2 tests pass: yes
fixes the following tickets: #3427
Todo: Doc + rebase + shash
(TP) @stof I fixed your remarks.
(FP) I might need some help with the configuration class, I am not very good at it.
(TP) @stof fixed, thanks and sorry for the mess.
I ran tests this time.

(TP) A few comments (I have just looked at this quickly, they might not be applicable)

* Should the cache warmer be updated ?
(FN) * I would like to see some tests exercising Bundle inheritance.
(TP) For ref, i think the AsseticBundle might need to be updated also.
(TP) the cache warmer indeed needs to be updated
(FP) @vicb yes, ths cache warmer needs to be updated, I am looking into it.
I will also look into tests for inherited bundles... even if I don't know how yet.

(TP) For bundle inheritance, the templates will need to be placed in a folder according to the config of the parent bundle, not of the current one, as the lookup for the overwriting template is done by the file locator, not by the template reference
@stof is this making this PR invalid?
(FP) Or can we find another way to fix this?
The bundle inheritance was handled in `Kernel::locateResource` to be exact (I haven't check if this PR modifies this).
(TP) @michelsalib I don't see another way for the inheritance, except reimplementing the whole child bundle lookup in the template reference (which is totally wrong IMO).

(TP) So if we make the directory configurable, we simply need to document this IMO (thus, changing this directory is only meaningful for app-specific bundles and I would advice using the ``app/Resources`` folder first to overwrite templates instead of creating a bunch of bundles just for it)
(FP) @stof I was about to make the same conclusion.
(FP) So, I agree with you.
(TP) I am going to submit fix and tests for the cache warmer.
(TP) I just updated the cache warmer.
(TP) I also add unit tests (maybe those needs to be refactored).
(TP) In order to keep track.
(TP) Like @vicb said, the AsseticBundle will need to be updated here : https://github.com/symfony/AsseticBundle/blob/master/DependencyInjection/Compiler/TemplateResourcesPass.php
On another note.
(TP) The more i think about it, the more I would feel better to add a `getViewDirectory` to the `BundleInterface`.
(TP) This way you would need to override a default function in the Bundle class, avoiding yourself to override other bundle directories too easily.
(FN) Also the code would be much cleaner and more OOP/SOC (which is what I love in Symfony2).
@michelsalib Please rebase your branch.
It conflicts with master.
@fabpot what do you think about it ?
@stof Done!
(FP) Waiting for comments in order to (IMPROVE) this PR.
Well, I have a weird failling test.
Let me check that.
Hum... apparently, this isn't me...
(FP) I'm -1 on making this configurable but I'm open to suggestion on how to (IMPROVE) the current situation.
(FP) @fabpot I agree with you that such a feature should no be configurable.
(FN) That is why I would prefer to add a method in BundleInterface that developers can override, and which should return path for view templates.
(TP) you can read my comments just above when I talked about that.
(TP) I'm closing this PR as we won't make this configurable.
(TP) Note that you can put all your template under the `app/Resources` directory if you want; it makes the path a bit shorter.

title: Add config which enables gzip compression, Disabled by default
body: Setting `config.gzip_compression = true` will load the `Rack::Deflater` middleware & enable gzip compression.
(FND) This config setting is useful if the HTTP requests terminates directly at app server & no longer goes through a web  server(Example Heroku's Cedar stack).
(TPD) therefore, gzip compression becomes responsibility of rack middleware.
In absence of this setting, people have resorted to hacking [config.ru directly](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7236583/where-to-insert-rackdeflater-in-the-rack).
(TPD) this patch provides a clean way, if anyone want to enable gzip compression at app server level
(TP) Thanks but I honestly don't feel the need for such configuration option.
(FN) A developer can simply call `use Rack::Deflater` in his `config/application.rb` or even in `config.ru`, it is not a hack at all.
(TP) in fact, we could even remove some of the configuration options we have and simply replace by their `use` counterpart in today's code.
(TP) although I am not sure if the backwards incompatibility is worth the effort.
(FP) Alright, makes sense.
Thanks for reviewing

title: [Finder] Ignore .AppleDouble directories
body: I'm having trouble with .AppleDouble directories, which are picked up when I run commands from the command line.
Symfony expects the wrong classes in the files "inside" the .AppeDouble directories.
(FPD) Of course Symfony2 should just ignore the .AppleDouble directory as there is only metadata in there.
(TPD) These issue already came up in https://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/994 and apparently was fixed in https://github.com/symfony/symfony/commit/7ab3fdeb8325d5a72c44dc73214c97f366a11c4c.
(FPD) This does not work for me however.
(TPD) i think the problem is that .AppleDouble is a directory, not a file.
(TPD) If I add .AppleDouble to the VCS patterns, it works and no files "inside" .AppleDouble are picked up.
(TPD) Of course, this does not seem to be the "right" way of doing this.
(FND) My thinking would be to rename $vcsPatterns to $directoryPatterns.
(FPD) If that sounds good, I'm happy to make a pull request.
(TP) duplicate of #4911 for which a fix is in progress in #5128

title: brew upgrade -v gettext fails with undefined method `include?' for nil:NilClass
body: Error: undefined method `include?'

(FPD) for nil:NilClass

https://gist.github.com/1449626


As a result (or because) the symlinks in /usr/local/lib are not created for libgettext.
(TP) duplicate of #7940.

(TP) Also documented on the "Common Issues" page of the wiki:

https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/wiki/Common-Issues
(TP) >As a result (or because) the symlinks in /usr/local/lib are not created for libgettext.
(TP) Also note that gettext is keg-only, so symlinks are never created in /usr/local/* unless you explicitly `brew link gettext` (which is not recommended).

title: fix crash when stopping music - FRODO FOOD!
body: When paplayer gets stopped in the last 5 secs where the next stream is already slaved the stop is blocked until the next track starts (no clue draining the stream i guess).
In that case the onplaybackstarted callback for the next track is fired even if we are about to stop.
In the message handler the current playlist is fetched and accessed directly with [] operator without checking if the playlist is still valid.
(FPD) This leads to bad access crashing because the playlist is empty already when the started message gets processed.

(TPD) This fix just fetches the playlist and checks the size before accessing the playlist item - fixes #13792

This is for frodo.
(TPD) I'm doing it as a PR because i was unsure if the early return true is right in that case.
(TPD) Talked about it with Montellese already and Martijn verified that this fixes the crash for windows too (and i did tests on osx).
@davilla @jmarshallnz for review
Looks OK.

(FN) I'd be tempted to reset m_nextPlaylistItem to -1 as well in both branches of that code (it'll normally be reset when you play something next, or the next file gets queued, but it should really be reset as soon as we've used it).
(TP) Well your call (or davillas maybe) cause i don't know what else of behaviour that would change.
(FN) (i would say "don't listen to the voices" for frodo if you are not 100 percent sure that it won't add regressions <- now thats impossible i guess haha).

Well, there's 2 choices here:

1. early return (i.e.
(FN) ignore the GUI_MSG_PLAYBACK_STARTED event).
(TP) 2. ignore the change of m_currentFile or whatever it is by moving the check into the first if() block.

(FN) I suspect the 2nd is less likely to result in regressions, but I'm not sure exactly what the expected behaviour is here (the playlist has been cleared, but the message is being fired even though the player is stopped?)
(FN) Does GUI_MSG_PLAYBACK_STOPPED get sent straight after, or is this is a rogue event.
If so, perhaps the rogue event should be eliminated in paplayer ?
Its some sort of race.
Start message is fired - player is stopped - start message is processed...
(TP) I had 2. implemented before but was unsure if it was ok to do the rest of the message handler so i added the return true for that special case.
(TP) Both appraoches fixed the crash of course
I'm ok with either
This well could be the cause of issue I reported here: http://forum.xbmc.org/showthread.php?tid=141224&page=22
There is a potential deadlock in master as well where a draining stream is fading in PAPlayer::SoftStop and it can hang when PAPlayer exits - may be related.
(FP) I decided to pull this in as is (because imo this start message is invalid and should just do nothing).

title: Link coreutils commands that do not conflict
body:
The coreutils formula installs all of its commands with a prefix of 'g'
in order to prevent collision with OSX commands.

(TPD) This change preserves
this behavior and creates an additional, non-prefixed link to commands
which do not have a conflicting OSX version, e.g., ```dircolors```.

(TPD) An alternative appraoch would be to list the ```gnubin``` at the end of
the PATH, but this requires an additional manual installation step.

(TPD) **Including the extra links eliminates this manual step and means the
missing OSX commands will 'just work' -- presumably the reason the user
installed the formula in the first place.

(TPD)**

Links are also created for the man pages to non-conflicting commands.
The list of non-conflicting commands is built by hand.

(TPD) This was done in
favor of some form of automation so that: 1) it is obvious which
commands are made available through this change, and 2) so that the list
can be easily modified in future releases in case a command is deemed
dangerous or (otherWISE) not a good idea to have readily available.
(FP) fyi - first PR to homebrew, so please excuse any rookie mistakes & advise (IMPROVE)ments.
(FP) I verified that the ```remove``` command cleans up properly after this change.
Thanks for considering!
Maintainers: I'm -0 on this but could be persuaded.
(FP) This seems pretty reasonable to me.
The premise is a bit dubious to me.
The reason I install coreutils is to get *better* versions of some tools, not to get missing tools.
Most of the tools affected by this are pretty obscure to begin with.
(TP) i think at the end of the day, installing coreutils without adjusting the path to include `gnubin` isn't going to help a lot of users.
(TP) (for example, what do you need `dircolors` for if you are not going to use GNU `ls`?)
For my situation it came down to simplification.
(TP) I *do* alias my ```ls``` to the gnu version and that works just fine.

(TP) however, a command like ```dircolors``` is typically tested for & called somewhere within a user's startup scripts and it's quite possible that this will have taken place before the aliases are established.
(TP) for example, I'm using ```zsh``` with [sorin-ionescu/prezto](https://github.com/sorin-ionescu/prezto) and the ```LS_COLORS``` is set before my aliases.

(TP) My preferred fix for this is to have a link to the ```dircolors``` command available in the normal path rather than adding an OSX-specific path to my dotfiles, since I use them on other platforms.
(TP) (Granted, I already have some system-specific aliases, but the fewer conditionals the better, IMO, and it still doesn't address the ordering issue.)

(TP) To be clear: _Not wanting to remember to create that one-off link when I set up a new OSX system is what motivated the PR._ Certainly I could just add this step to my setup script, but had a spare hour so thought I'd propose the change.
I defer to the maintainers' vote on this one.
(TP) i think it's both useful and harmless, but I will concede that it isn't a must-have feature.
Based on that explanation, this looks like an awfully specific use case.
(TP) I would look for a fix in your shell setup first.
> Not wanting to remember to create that one-off link when I set up a new OSX system is what motivated the PR.
(FN) Possibly something that could be added to your dot-files?
https://github.com/adamv/dotfiles
(FP) agreed that my use case is specific and that there are ways around this in my dotfiles; just thought there may have been some additional use for this beyond my needs.
(FP) Sounds like this isn't a desired change, I'm going to close this PR.

title: fix incorrect usage `require mysql` in the activerecord/.../mysql_rake_test
body: `require mysql` used here for the 6 **hard** mysql-spesifics tests only (see [MysqlDBcreateAsRootTest](https://github.com/rimidl/rails/pull/new/fix-incorrect-require-mysql-in-mysql_rake_test#L0R46)).
(FND) But we don't should run it for the sqlite or postgresql database contexts.
(TPD) And of course we don't should `require mysql`, when we run tests only for sqlite (`ARCONN=sqlite3 ruby -Itest .../mysql_rake_test.rb`), for example.

(FND) \+ if we follow the guides [Set up and Run the Tests](http://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#set-up-and-run-the-tests) ,
we naturally catch error bellow:

```
rails/ $ rm .bundle/config
rails/ $ bundle install --without db
rails/ $ cd activerecord
activerecord/ $ ARCONN=mysql ruby -Itest test/cases/tasks/mysql_rake_test.rb
...
(mysql is not part of the bundle.
(FND) Add it to Gemfile.)

(TPD) (LoadError)
...
```

This pull-request fix this error.
(TPD) _Note:_ `MysqlDBcreateAsRootTest` don't pass with mysql2 adapter, only with mysql.

title: Cmake fails to link when /Library/Frameworks/expat.framework exists
body: (FPD) With the help of amiller and mustardhamsters in irc, we tracked down that if the user has a file "/Library/Frameworks/expat.framework" present, then Cmake will attempt to link against that version of expat instead of /usr/lib/libexpat.dylib.
This is almost certainly the source of the random _XML_* linking errors we've seen in this formula.
(FND) I'll be adding checks to "brew doctor" and the cmake brew itself for this framework.
(If we could figure out what software, possibly .pkg-based was installing it, that would be good too.)
(FP) Ah, nice work.
(TP) Partially implemented in 22e34998afc6842adea456e5c2e27c59ef0938ef
Pulled doctor check into my refactor branch, so closing this.
