title: postgresql: adding --universal support
body: Here is the squashed commits from #14036 to consider for merging.
(TPD) It adds universal support to ``postgresql`` and ``ossp-uuid``.

(TP) Some [conversation](http://archives.postgresql.org/pgsql-hackers/2012-08/msg00267.php) took place on the ``pgsql-hackers`` mailing list but, aside from their fascination with ``ed`` scripts, the only suggestion was to [configure and build it twice and merge the resulting binaries together](http://archives.postgresql.org/pgsql-hackers/2012-08/msg00352.php) which isn't really how universal builds work or to [follow instructions from 2008](http://archives.postgresql.org/pgsql-hackers/2008-07/msg00884.php) which essentially say to hack the config files.

(TP) If you want to merge this, it works fine for me, but if you just want to leave this patch for anyone [looking for universal support](https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/14032) thats fine too.
(TP) I take comfort that this is how MacPorts works.

I'm not sure if Fink provides universal binaries as I don't see evidence of it in their [postgresql91 info script](http://fink.cvs.sourceforge.net/fink/dists/10.7/stable/main/finkinfo/database/postgresql91.info?view=markup).
(FP) Passing on this for now; but would review new patches rebased on master, one formula per pull request.

> the only suggestion was to configure and build it twice and merge the resulting binaries together which isn't really how universal builds work

actually, that is exactly how universal builds work.
When you pass multiple `-arch` flags to an Apple compiler what happens behind the scenes is that it compiles the binary twice and splices the result together with `lipo`.

(TP) An example of doing this by hand can be found in the ZeroMQ formula:

  https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/blob/5a900e8/Library/Formula/zeromq.rb#L36-52
(FP) If that is a better way of doing it (and i think it might be), I can update the pull request to match that behavior?
What do you think?
Closing in favor of #14775.

title: Nestable blueprints
body: (FND) I'd like to be able to register "sub-blueprints" using `Blueprint.register_blueprint(*args, **kwargs)`.
(FND) This would register the nested blueprints with an app when the "parent" is registered with it.
(TPD) All parameters are preserved, other than `url_prefix`, which is handled similarly to in `add_url_rule`.
(FP) I agree, this is something I'd like to see as well.
(TP) i think the best use case would be a modular admin panel, where it is kept in a blueprint and plugins create sub-blueprints that are added to that blueprint.
(FP) I've been using the following for now for a thing I've been working on.
(TP) While there are no guarantees etc I haven't encountered any major issues with it so far.
Not sure what the semantics are for this.
(TP) If someone wants this, please come up with a design for it :)
(TP) i think that dontcare4free's NestableBlueprint provides a good rough design.
(TP) All that would really be needed is the ability to register blueprints onto an already existing blueprint.

(TP) I don't think this would really change any code in Blueprint.register() either since, from looking at that and BlueprintSetupState, the same function names are shared between Blueprint and Flask.
(FN) Looks like it'd be mostly a duplication of register_blueprint from Flask to Blueprint.

(TP) Here is how I'd envision Blueprint.register_blueprint would work:

Each blueprint would have its own self.blueprints dict.
(TP) When register_blueprint is called, it would check whether there is a blueprint with that name already in its internal dict.
(TP) The logic on what to depending on that result do is duplicated between Flask.register_blueprint and Blueprint.register_blueprint.
(TP) however, the ID of the child blueprint would have the id of the parent blueprint appended to it, with a '.'
between the two.
(TP) for example, if the parent blueprint was named 'config' and the child blueprint was named 'users', then ultimately its ID would be 'config.users'.
(FN) Any paths in the child would be prefixed by the parent blueprint's url_prefix as well as the child's.
(TP) This is equally as rough as the dontcare4free's design above, and I haven't looked thoroughly through the code to see everywhere that this could affect, but it is possible to do.
+1 on @dontcare4free's code
I'm also hoping for this.

(TP) Right now, I'm implementing a RESTful API alongside a traditional web application and am ending up writing a lot of non-DRY code because I can't nest blueprints, particularly wrt API error handling (i.e., I have to override Flask's build-in error handling for each API blueprint in the same way).
(TP) in fact, I'm thinking of trying out dontcare4free's NestableBlueprints subclass to see if it would help solve my problem.
I'd love it if this were built in.
:+1: for adapting the snippet above in the builtin Blueprint class
Nested Blueprints would be extremely handy.
I could use something like this as well.
Not sure about the design, though – will test-drive it in my application.
How strange - `flask.Flask` and `flask.Blueprint` are getting more and more similar.
Maybe they should inherit from a common class?
(FP) @gioi I already suggested something along these lines once in IRC and got some arguments against it (by @mitsuhiko ?
i don't remember) but i can't recall the points that were made against it.
I also suck at grepping the logs.
Personally, I like the idea of inheriting from a common class.
I like to build my blueprints as fairly isolated from their siblings.
(TP) It would be kind of nice if a blueprint was just a flask app itself.
(FN) Perhaps there could be a distinction between blueprints that have to be bolted onto a parent, and blueprints/apps that can be run standalone.
There is a lot of overlap between the two.
(TP) i think bringing them closer together could really allow for some powerful uses.

To elaborate on my personal use case:

A specific application contains about two dozen blueprints.
Most are coupled with a single entity (one pair for users, news posts, etc.)
and contain the usual view methods (create, update, delete, etc.).
(TP) however, some blueprints and entities belong together (news posts and images, gallery albums and images, etc.
), and that's why I would like to group them together, but preferably without sacrificing the namespace-free view methods (as opposed to switching to `create_post`, `create_image`, etc.
(FN) and combining them in the same blueprint Python module).
(TP) So what I'm actually looking for is a way to group blueprints; but there is no need to (infinitely) nest them.
(TP) @homeworkprod AFAIU, nestable blueprints would be a solution to your problem, right?
@mitsuhiko Is this going anywhere?
(FP) This seems like a great idea.
(FP) @gioi: Well, they would be _a_ solution, but I'm worried that this would go too far.

(TP) The initial post speaks of "sub-blueprints", and i think one additional layer would suffice (versus "nested", which, to me, sounds like multiple layers, and people could really go wild with that).
(FP) But then again I might see a problem here that doesn't exist.
(TP) Wouldn't a proper implementation of "sub-blueprints" pretty much automatically support infinite nesting of blueprints, too, anyway?

Some questions to examine the current proposal:
- Would this mean we'd have endpoints like `admin.news.posts.tags.update`?
- Based on the `.view` shortcuts, how would one relatively reference a sub-blueprint in an `url_for` call in a (first-level) blueprint's template?
- Would `..view` in a sub-blueprint point to the parent's `view` function?
(FP) @ThiefMaster: Well, I'd say it could get more complex, as it is usually the case with generalized implementations.
But basically, yes, likely.

@homeworkprod 

> * Would this mean we'd have endpoints like `admin.news.posts.tags.update`?
(FP) The implementation in the OP doesn't handle this, but i think that makes the most sense.

title: set multicast loop and set multicast ttl
body: (TPD) Add udp methods to set multicast loopback and ttl socket options.

LGTM.
(TP) Can you add tests?
@shtylman: Can you add the tests?
I'm fine with tests that simply set the TTL / loopback flag and check the return code (a loopback test helper gets you extra karma points, though :-).
(FP) I want to repurpose the old multicast test in Node, this pull request is one of the missing pieces.
(FP) I started working on the tests however ran into a bit of a snag.
(FP) I am not sure how this deferred fd assignment is supposed to work.
(FP) Apparently, the handle fd is not set on uv_udp_init but instead this happens sometime later.
(FP) A bind call supposedly sets it but this is not needed for sending multicast packets.
Any pointers on how to understand the fd assignment would be appreciated :)
(TP) `uv__udp_maybe_deferred_bind()` will create the file descriptor for you (come to think of it, `uv_udp_set_membership()` should probably do that too).
(TP) If binding is not desirable, `uv__udp_maybe_deferred_bind()` should be split into two functions: one to create the socket, the other to do the binding.

The new node.js version will release and one major hole still is the udp side of things.

Let's get this into 0.7 soon.

title: ElasticSearch shell script fails due to unsupported syntax on non-Bash shells
body: The first line of the elasticsearch script specifies `/bin/sh`, but this is generally defined as pointing to a Bourne-compatible shell.
It cannot be assumed to point to Bash shell.

Line 92 contains the followin:

 `JAVA=$(which java)`

1.
(TPD) The first line should be changed to /bin/bash if that is intended.

(TPD) Or line 92 must be changed so that `which java` is surrounded within backtics, which is the only common (though not able to be nested) syntax across all Bourne-derived shells (Bourne, Dash, Korn, Bash).
Thank you.
Brian Yoder
Empty

title: (image/video/audio)_path helpers break route urls
body: It took me ages, and the help of Radar on IRC channel (thank you Radar) to track down this bug.
In `actionpack/lib/action_view/helpers/asset_tag_helper.rb` there are three methods, image_path, video_path, and audio_path.
These three methods are available in the view scope, rather than internally only, which causes issues when you have an ActiveRecord model and routes of either Image, Video, or Audio.
In my case, I have a  video.rb with a class of Video, inheriting from ActiveRecord::Base.
(FPD) When I do a `url_for(Video.first)`, the url generation is broken and throws and error, because it's trying to use the asset_tag_helper.rb video_path, rather than the routes video_path.
This bug affects Rails 3.0.10 onward (including the current codebase targeted to become Rails 4.0).
(FPD) Any known work arounds that don't include changing my entire codebase to not use a model called Video ?
(TP) We fixed this in sprockets-rails integration, I will provide a patch for this later today (but I'm not sure if it will be merged only in master or it should be fixed in all the other branches)
I could really do with this in 3.0.x branch.
(FP) Now that I've noticed it, it's actually preventing me from doing a lot of things.
(FP) Is there a temporary work around (method override?)
(FP) or can it only be fixed within Rails?
> I could really do with this in 3.0.x branch.
< 3.2 is security fixes only, just so you know.
(TP) You may want to clone your own rails, add this patch manually, and use your fork.
yay bundler!
(TP) i think we will still merge bug fix pull requests against 3-0-stable but there won't be any releases other than when there is a security fix.
(FP) I couldn't check this soon (*cof* final exams *cof*), if someone want to fix this please go ahead :smile:
(TP) I'm closing this here since Core Team isn't taking care of bugs for 3.0.x, if you want you can send a PR fixing it but I'm not sure if it will be merged :grin:

title: "Not" constraints generate a confusing error message
body:
(FPD) This assertion:

```$this->assertNotContains('required', 'username is required');```

generates the following error message:

```Failed asserting that 'username is not required' does not contain "required"```

Note that 'username is required' has been changed to 'username is *not* required'

I tracked this down to Framework/Constraint/Not::failureDescription which calls the "negate" method.
(FPD) I see the reason for this is to change the constraint error message appropriately, but it also changes the output that was being tested as well - which mystified me until I tracked this down.
I can see due to the way the message is already generated that Not.php may not be able to reliably figure out what is part of the PHPUnit error and what is the output being tested.
If I were to come up with something would a pull request be considered?

He,

thanks for the bug report and for tracking this down.
This is definitely strange and not expected or desired so I'd consider it a bug.
(FP) If you can come up with a nicer solution to this I'd be happy about a PR :)
cool.

(FP) the problem as i can see it is that at that stage the constraint just has an error message that was generated somewhere earlier in the chain and so it doesn't know within that scope what part of the message is phpunit text, and what part is the output from the expression that was being tested.
(TP) so one appraoch could be a more specific pattern matching, but i'm thinking that might not be able to catch everything.
(TP) a slightly more disruptive change would be for phpunit to generate it's text as a kind of simplistic template language and then right before it gets sent back, the search/replace happens.

(TP) for example the first constrain could generate a message like this:

```
Failed asserting that 'username not required' {{contains}} "required"
```

Then the Not constraint would be able to locate text generated by phpunit because it is surrounded by brackets and could safely replace {{contains}} with {{does not contain}}.
(TP) Lastly at the very end just before the result message is sent back, a global function could look for any template vars and replace them.
(TP) It seems kinda overkill for such a minor thing but I'm not sure there is a better way without doing some major plumbing changes.
Thanks for looking into that!
Not really sure what to do about it ether.
(TP) Maybe the simplest case that might catch most of the issues is only doing the replace for stuff outside of single and double quotes.
Not sure.
Leaving this open for anyone to pick up :)
(FP) Long time ago in one of the projects that I was working on we had to perform operations on stuff that were outside of single and double quotes.
We used a regex similar to the one below to match them.
(TP) If doing replace on the matched stuff is sufficient for solving this issue the solution is straightforward using the regex below.

title: nav-bar adds extra empty box to the right
body: (FPD) using the example documentation for nav-bar as mentioned on foundation.zurb.com/docs/ui.php produces 5 boxes for the navigation, one for each NavItem and one empty box all the way to the right.
Is there a way to disable this box?
Here is an example for the nav-bar that exhibits the issue that I reported above.
It shows the 4 nav items but has an extra box with nothing in it after "Nav Item 4".
(FP) The top-bar used by zurb website does not seem to exhibit this behavior.

```html
  • Nav Item 1
  • Nav Item 2
  • Nav Item 3
  • Nav Item 4
```
The box you're seeing is simply the border around the entire element, which is width: auto and thus full width.
(TP) (YOU COULD) remove this by modifying the style for a nav bar to have no border around the UL itself, and only around the list items.

title: patch for issue #2820
body: (TPD) This is a patch for issue #2820 ("ActiveRecord 3.1 does not restore connection inheritance after establish_connection/remove_connection on a model").
(TPD) It applies the solution described in that ticket.
(TPD) There is also a change in `connection_adapters/abstract/connection_specification.rb` to ensure that a `nil` pool can't leak out and cause `NoMethodError`s.
This pull request is against 3-1-stable.
(TPD) I've verified that the patch also works on master.

title: Lighthouse 3353
body: There was an issue that belongs_to associations with autosave enabled calls save and all callbacks every time the parent record was saved.
This results in unexpected behaviour.
(TPD) I've changed this to only call save if the associated record is changed.
I believe this can be pushed to the 3-0-stable branch as well
(FP) This looks good, do you test to make sure assocs are not saved if they have not changed?

(FP) This seems to be already in master:

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/lib/active_record/autosave_association.rb#L394
Test: https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/test/cases/autosave_association_test.rb#L683
(TP) I added an extra test to check if save is indeed not called when the associated record has not changed.
This pull request is indeed already in master for some time.
What should i do to get this in a stable release soon?
@chielwester Rails 3.1 is getting released soon, so I am closing this issue.
(TP) When 3.1 is out and you feel you need this on 3-0-stable, please reopen the issue.
Thanks for your pull request.

body:

Mac OS X 10.7.3

Binary.

title: fix human_attribute_name to handle names with dots
body: Nested I18n namespace lookup under activerecord.models is deprecated now (c19bd4f).

But when a model uses accepts_nested_attributes_for, its Errors object can have
an attribute name with "addresses.street" style.

(FND) In this case, the dots should be
substituted with slashes so that we can provide the translation under the
"activemodel.attributes.person.addresses/street" key.
(FP) @kuroda If I want multi-level nested attributes, what should I do to define the locale?
(FP) For your example, you have just location/address.
If I have customer/person/location/address, what should I do?

(TP) @torsakch 

although I have enough time to check it out now, i think that current implementation can not handle correctly the deeply (more than two-level) nested attributes.
(TP) In that case, we should make a new patch and send a pull request.
(FP) @kuroda Do you have work around solution?
Not yet.
It should not be difficult, but I am a little busy now.
I'm new to Rails (and programming in general), so please forgive me if I'm posting out of turn here.
I noticed this issue is marked as closed.
(FP) I'm having trouble localizing nested attributes, so I'm wondering if I'm doing something wrong or if this issue still remains.
I'm on Rails 3.2.3.
Thank you.
As for deeply nested attributes, this issue is still open.
Ok, thank you!
(TP) i think this patch should be back-ported to Rails 3.1
@leehambley OK.
I will do that job.
Please wait a few days.
@kuroda Thanks very much, I was referred to this issue from AASM https://github.com/rubyist/aasm/issues/38
@leehambley I have sent a pull request of a backport to Rails 3.2.
(FP) It seems that this fix is not relevant to Rails 3.1.
Correct me if I am wrong.
> It seems that this fix is not relevant to Rails 3.1.
Correct me if I am wrong.

(FP) It seems it's unrelated to the warning I am receiving out of AASM; aasm uses "#{state_columln}.#{model_state}" for i18n'ing keys, example:

``` yaml
activerecord:
   attributes:
      user:
        state:
          confirmed: "Bestätigt" # Confirmed
          locked: "Gesperrt" # Locked
```

The same warning is being raised, but apparently for a different reason.

title: keep flash when redirecting via force_ssl
body: (TPD) need to keep flash messages when do redirecting via force_ssl method.

(TPD) Here is a patch:

```diff
diff --git a/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/force_ssl.rb b/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/force_ssl.rb
index ed693c5..b255115 100644
--- a/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/force_ssl.rb
+++ b/actionpack/lib/action_controller/metal/force_ssl.rb
@@ -26,10 +26,11 @@ module ActionController
       def force_ssl(options = {})
         before_filter(options) do
           if !request.ssl?
&& !Rails.env.development?

+            flash.keep
             redirect_to :protocol => 'https://', :status => :moved_permanently
           end
         end
       end
     end
   end
-end
\ No newline at end of file
+end
```
+1 on this issue
(FP) How does this work if your session cookie is HTTPS only?

any update on this?

(TP) So, for example:

1.
(FN) User goes to action which requires authentication.

(FN) He redirects to login form with flash message "Please login first"
3.
(FN) But login action has filter force_ssl and redirects user to https.

title: Gitlab::Encode.utf8 should be aware of encoding header in commits.
body: I should note that Git saves commit messages in any encoding.
Typically it is UTF-8, but it depends on commit author locale settings.
Git adds encoding header to the commit if commit message encoding isn't utf-8.
So Gitlab::Encode.utf8 or CommitDecorator should be aware of encoding header.
Now Gitlab simply dies to some commit messages like KOI-8R.

(TPD) It looks like: 
2012-08-02_09:10:32.16501 unknown header 'encoding' in commit b18d6d46f37e4756a238cc209d1231952cb80088

2012-08-02_09:10:32.43614

2012-08-02_09:10:32.43616     8:       %strong.cgray= commit.author_name
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43617     9:       –
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43617     10:       = image_tag gravatar_icon(commit.author_email), :class => "avatar", :width => 16
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43618     11:       %span.row_title= truncate(commit.title, :length => 50)
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43618     12: 
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43619     13:       %span.committed_ago
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43619     14:         = time_ago_in_words(commit.committed_date)
2012-08-02_09:10:32.43620   lib/gitlab/encode.rb:51:in `force_encoding'
Line number in Encode is not like your master because I did some modifications of code to do it more encodings friendly.
My corrections of some troubleshootings (#1003) were rejected but I permanently handle a lot of projects that uses koi8-r, windows-1251,, utf-8 etc.
encodings.
Hi, @akzhan .
what version of GITLAB did u use?
[lib/gitlab/encode.rb](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/lib/gitlab/encode.rb) only has 41 lines.

```ruby

 => false

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO-8859-8-I
@akzhan Did u know how to get the encoding header, use grit?
(FP) @SaitoWu As I seen now - it should be patched in Grit.
Will do.

title: Brewing Lilypond --with-docs fails under 10.7.5
body: Raring to brew, as always.
Here's the [install.log](https://gist.github.com/4013667) and the [config.log](https://gist.github.com/4013685).
I get a SIG11 (segmentation fault) while compiling the docs, consistently at the same point in the process after many attempts.
My hardware is  well-behaving and I never get kernel panics or anything similar (i.e.
not a hardware-induced fault).
I did not have the issue a few months ago under 10.7.4 and the same Lilypond version.
(FPD) It seems to me possible that the lilypond binaries produced in this brew are not of high quality.
But why?
Good question.
(TP) EDIT: To save everyone having to read 40 comments... lilypond is missing a dependency on `fondu` and `env :std` for 10.7.
(TP) That fixes things pretty much.

(TP) ----------
Building docs is a latex thing, iirc, that is sensitive to 3rd party python modules you might have since installed.
(FN) A sig 11 is a software error telling you that there was some unexpected code clash, not a kernel panic as you mentioned.
(TP) So don't so much think about the exact error as decide whether you are willing to minimize the variables and move `/usr/local` to `/usr/local.bak` and reinstall.
(TP) I used MacTex 2012 when I was testing, and I'm fairly confident you can succeed here, eventually.

(TP) I just meant that SIG11 sometimes signifies a hardware fault, usually memory-related, but I can rule this possibility out in this case as I have been facing no other hardware-related issues such as kernel panics.
(TP) Building the Lilypond docs actually invokes Lilypond itself, typesetting tons of music examples.
(TP) As you may see in the [install.log](https://gist.github.com/4013667) (now fixed—previously it was truncated, sorry) the failing command is actually an invocation of `lilypond` not of `latex`.
I have a very minimal installation of Python, basically only `fontforge` and `dblatex` (both required for Lilypond).

```
(530) (0) (lilydblatex) ▼  /usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages>  ls
total 96
drwxr-xr-x   5 rammos  admin   170 Nov  3 20:29 dblatex-0.3.4-py2.7.egg
drwxr-xr-x  10 rammos  admin   340 Nov  4 22:08 distribute-0.6.28-py2.7.egg
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin   263 Nov  3 20:29 easy-install.pth
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin   223 Nov  3 20:17 fontforge-1.0-py2.7.egg-info
-rwxr-xr-x   1 rammos  admin  8916 Nov  3 20:17 fontforge.so
drwxr-xr-x   4 rammos  admin   136 Nov  4 22:08 pip-1.2.1-py2.7.egg
-rwxr-xr-x   1 rammos  admin  8900 Nov  3 20:17 psMat.so
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin   144 Nov  2 22:37 setuptools-0.6c11-py2.7.egg-info
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin    30 Nov  4 22:08 setuptools.pth
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin  1224 Nov  4 22:07 sitecustomize.py
-rw-r--r--   1 rammos  admin   600 Nov  4 22:08 sitecustomize.pyc
```

The offending command (triggering the SIG11) is:

```
command failed: /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/out/bin/lilypond -I ./ 
-I ./out-www -I ../../input -I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation 
-I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/snippets/out -I ../../input/regression/ 
-I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/included/ 
-I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/mf/out/ -I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/mf/out/ 
-I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/pictures 
-I /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/pictures/./out-www -dbackend=eps --formats=ps,png,pdf  
-dinclude-eps-fonts -dgs-load-fonts --header=doctitle --header=doctitlecs --header=doctitlede 
--header=doctitlees --header=doctitlefr --header=doctitlehu --header=doctitleit --header=doctitleja --header=doctitlenl 
--header=doctitlezh --header=texidoc --header=texidoccs --header=texidocde --header=texidoces --header=texidocfr 
--header=texidochu --header=texidocit --header=texidocja --header=texidocnl --header=texidoczh -dcheck-internal-types 
-ddump-signatures -danti-alias-factor=2 -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/out/lybook-db"  -I  "."

-I  ".."  
-I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/input/regression"  -I  "./"  -I  "./out-www"  -I  "../../input"  
-I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation"  -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/snippets/out"  
-I  "../../input/regression/"  -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/included/" 
 -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/mf/out/"  -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/mf/out/" 
 -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/pictures"  
-I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/documentation/pictures/./out-www" --formats=eps  -deps-box-padding=3.000000  
-dread-file-list -dno-strip-output-dir  "/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/out/lybook-db/snippet-names-9041008349041401427.ly"
Child was terminated by signal 11
Error ignored by lilylib
Error trapped by lilypond-book
```

Notably, just before this there is a very similar invocation, which completes without problems.

```
/private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/out/bin/lilypond -dbackend=eps --formats=ps,png,pdf  -dinclude-eps-fonts 
-dgs-load-fonts --header=doctitle --header=doctitlecs --header=doctitlede --header=doctitlees --header=doctitlefr 
--header=doctitlehu --header=doctitleit --header=doctitleja --header=doctitlenl --header=doctitlezh --header=texidoc 
--header=texidoccs --header=texidocde --header=texidoces --header=texidocfr --header=texidochu --header=texidocit 
-header=texidocja --header=texidocnl --header=texidoczh -dcheck-internal-types -ddump-signatures -danti-alias-factor=2' 
--output=./out-www --format=texi-html --loglevel=WARN  --lily-output-dir /private/tmp/lilypond-Mdbj/lilypond-2.16.0/out/lybook-db 
--redirect-lilypond-output AAA-intro-regression.tely
```

Basically, the two invocations differ only in the source file they typeset and the search dirs (`-I` arguments).
(TP) The error is trapped by `lilypond-book` because `lilypond` is executed within the `lilypond-book` Python script.
(FP) And this is as far as I can get at the moment...
Do you have a non USA locale or anything?
(FN) Try running the command manually.
Any more info then?
(FN) Maybe add a `-v` to the command if it accepts it.
(FN) Perhaps you will get more info if you run that command through gdb.
(TP) dblatex cause ghc to sig11 during the building of it's docs, and I only had dblatex installed because I used it to build lilypond.
(TP) So perhaps you can update your dblatex or reinstall it to be sure it's not the problem.
(TP) btw if you surround your terminal output with three backticks, it will all go into one easy to read code block.

(TP) for example:

    ```
    Here is some text.
(TP) And another line.

(TP) ```

would create this:

```
Here is some text.
(TP) And another line.
(TP) And the backticks need to be on their own line (which is what I forgot to do).
(FP) I can't run the offending command manually because the entire folder structure is temporary and deleted before the installer exits.
(FP) I could check the tarball and see if that would work but I doubt it.
(FP) Any way I can keep that temp folder and clean it up manually?
`dblatex` is in several ways quirky.
(FP) for example it can only be installed with `easy_install`, not `pip`.
I do have a non-English locale.
But I had it also last time I brewed the same ver of Lilypond+docs on 10.7.4 without problems.
I know, this doesn't prove much but…
(FP) I prefer the long single line, but that's just me.
Please gist your  `brew --config` and `brew doctor` and `brew list` outputs.

(TP) you can shell out into the temporary directory when the install errors with
```
brew install -v --with-doc lilypond
```
It should bring up a menu of 5 choices.
(FN) The last one is "Shell."
(FN) When you shell out after the error, please gist the output of `env`.
(TP) You leave the temporary bash shell with `exit 0` to finish a successful manual install, or `exit 1` if you want to bail out gracefully.
(TP) If (YOU COULD) build Lilypond with docs previously, that's important.
(TP) It's likely if you just remove and reinstall everything that this will work, but we should look at your gists of course.

```
sudo mv /usr/local /usr/local.bak
sudo mkdir /usr/local
sudo chown $USER:admin /usr/local
chmod 775 /usr/local
cd /usr/local
then run the Homebrew install
```
I'll try to build this on my Lion setup in the meantime.
Will do all that.
(TP) Meanwhile, please note that you need `--env=std` (the latter on my setup at least) to build the lilypond binaries.
(FP) It looks like the `-d` option is broken by an internal Homebrew readline related bug I reported last week.
We won't be able to use that.
I've been getting different build errors before I get to the docs part that I'm trying to sort out with `--env=std` and updating my OS.
(TP) You should read this: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/14559
(FP) I am actually the author of this :-)
(TP) Oh so you patched `/usr/include/FlexLexer.h` and get past `make`.
I'll try to get to that point tomorrow.
(TP) I was thinking all we needed was to `#include <stddef.h>` to get that `size_t` defined.
(FP) Perhaps I used a sledgehammer for a tiny nut but I thought to patch it as the FlexLexer.h file shipped with 10.8 has int replaced with size_t.
So does the latest version upstream.
(FP) Though it does make me a bit anxious to touch system libraries.

On 6 Nov 2012, at 11:27, 2bits <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Oh so you patched /usr/include/FlexLexer.h and get past make.
I'll try to get to that point tomorrow.
I was thinking all we needed was to #include <stddef.h> to get that size_t defined.

> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Do you have link to the bug report?
I did file it but it was more or less dismissed as uninteresting (my words).
Upstream seems content with distributing binaries, i think, and is not very concerned with debugging individual build systems.

On 6 Nov 2012, at 11:46, 2bits <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I forget, did this issue make it upstream?
Do you have link to the bug report?

> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Ok I'll try again.
(TP) We might need to brew flex from source and add it as a dependency.
(TP) working on this a bit as time permits, as there is no flex formula yet because it would be a dupe.
(TP) Yes, it would be ideal to include the latest version available at http://flex.sourceforge.net, overriding the version shipped with the OS.

(TP) Inspired by some similar bug reports (from older versions of Lilypond), and thinking that this is a somewhat elusive fluke, I modified the formula to build the docs one process (and on a single CPU) at a time:

`make -j1 CPU_COUNT=1 doc`

instead of the plain

`make doc`

No success, unfortunately, so we can rule out the possibility that this was due to CPU congestion.
(FP) I'll try to boot into 10.7 today and work on this.

Here is my `brew --config`:

```

(FP) Yea I figured it out by the fact that dblatex won't install unless you have HB python and by reading your install.log.
It's early here :-)
(FP) just to confirm that the SIG11 issue persists on my system after updating the formula to the newly released 2.16.1 version.
(Pull request: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/15959)
The fontforge formula is broken.

(TP) `make install` was not working for me because of that.
(TP) We might need to throw env=std for everyone for lilypond.
Don't know yet.
I'm curious if you set that docbook env var `XML_CATALOG_FILES` like the docbook caveats say to do before you tried to brew lilypond?
(FP) I just reproduced the Sig 11 error you are getting.
Yeah it is still set in my `.bashrc` from a previous install.
(FP) Strange that (YOU COULD)n't `make install` without tweaking fontforge.
My system didn't stumble on that...
Are you on 10.7.4 or 10.7.5?
And may I ask what your CPU is?
(FP) You probably had libpng and jpeg and libtiff installed already when you built fontforge.
I purposely wiped all my brews first to find these issues.
I'm duplicating your setup on 10.7.4.

Did you get 10.7.5 from the App Store as a regular user?
No, I got it via Software update in the OS.
Neither an App Store update nor a Combo download from the Apple website.

(TP) I've been digging a bit into the error this issue is about, 

```
command failed: /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/out/bin/lilypond -I ./ -I ./out-www -I ../../input -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/documentation -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/documentation/snippets/out -I ../../input/regression/ -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/documentation/included/ -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/mf/out/ -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/mf/out/ -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/documentation/pictures -I /private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/documentation/pictures/./out-www -dbackend=eps --formats=ps,png,pdf  -dinclude-eps-fonts -dgs-load-fonts --header=doctitle --header=doctitlecs --header=doctitlede --header=doctitlees --header=doctitlefr --header=doctitlehu --header=doctitleit --header=doctitleja --header=doctitlenl --header=doctitlezh --header=texidoc --header=texidoccs --header=texidocde --header=texidoces --header=texidocfr --header=texidochu --header=texidocit --header=texidocja --header=texidocnl --header=texidoczh -dcheck-internal-types -ddump-signatures -danti-alias-factor=2 -I  "/private/tmp/lilypond-J0Ua/lilypond-2.16.1/out/lybook-db"  -I  "."

http://lilypond.org/doc/v2.17/documentation/contributor-big-page#regression-tests

```rb
begin

rescue

title: Kestrel does not work on uni-processor boxes
body: (FPD) It seems that kestrel does not work properly on uniprocessor boxes, as maxThreads is initialized to 2, and a sanity check fails inside ThreadPoolExecutor in the actors library.
The condition is maximumPoolSize < corePoolSize.
corePoolSize is derived from minNumThreads which is initialized to 4 statically in FJTaskScheduler2.scala.

(TPD) I've fixed it in my tree, here: 
http://github.com/hugohallqvist/kestrel/commit/35b2999636c0835c7b8b94d69b8af6cfd5ed0920

(TP) I had a similar issue that I believe was a regression with Scala 2.7.7, I changed ivy/ivy.xml to use 2.7.5 (see: SHA: 54713ab79197273850adc84a27a0d8657b47628a) instead and everything works fine now.
(FP) Too bad I didn't find your changes before wasting a couple of hours debugging... :-)
(TP) patch taken!

title: API feature for ES update
body: (FPD) As we know, to update elasticsearch we need to follow some steps aka flush index, shutdown node etc.
(FPD) This works fine if we have only a few indices.
(TPD) But imagine we have a weekly-based (or even daily-based) indices ... this process requires to create some custom scripts to iterate through indices and prepare them (e.g.

(TPD) flush) ... sounds not reasonable and dangerous

It would be nice to have some API from elasticsearch which on call can prepare whole my cluster for update procedure.
(TPD) Besides that, in the future to this API (as a step of preparation) could be added an option to backup that cluster before (as soon as Backup API would be you released).
What do you think?
(FP) hey @gakhov I wonder what else than _flush should be called here.

(TP) you can call flush without specifying an index and flush all indices in the cluster (http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/reference/api/admin-indices-flush.html) using

```$ curl -XPOST 'http://localhost:9200/_flush'```

are you thinking of anything else?
hi!

(FP) @s1monw I don't really sure ... just wanted to have upgrade process more simple, since i'm a bit lazy .. lol

Currently, to upgrade ES i need to 
* prevent writing
* flush indices
* iterate through all nodes and do backup/stop/update/start (some downtime is acceptable for us, so we don't do the trick with renaming a cluster to keep frontend application running).
Of course, ES can't help me with the actual upgrading procedure, but I thought it can manage the preparation process.
(TP) Right now we update our ES nodes with deployment script (fabric and puppet), so we need just to be sure that ES cluster (and indices) is ready for that from the data state point of view.
(FN) In our case, we can't stop the indexation process, but if it receives write exception, the failed items will be rescheduled.
(TP) So, we need just to do `index.blocks.read_only` before starting the actual upgrade.
(FN) We don't use automatical shard allocation, so no worries about ES starting reallocate shards when nodes will go off for upgrade.
(FP) actually, i also thinking about the backup procedure (e.g.
with rsync), which requires data copy.
All these two require some common steps: at least flush and read_only.
And  thought it would be very useful  to have some standard way to do that, e.g.
shortcuts from ES API.
(TP) So, it might be `read_only` + `flush` as _backup_ preparation procedure and _backup_+(optionally)shutdown as upgrade prepration procedure.
In some cases, `optimize` also (e.g.

(FP) to 1 segment)

 Does it make sense for you?

(FP) hey @gakhov 

well laziness is good (otherWISE) there wouldn't be any automation I guess, I'm not really sure if I get this right so lets just clarify here if we are missing something API wise.
(TP) At the current stage if you are doing a code upgrade on ElasticSearch you don't need to necessarily prevent writing to ElasticSearch while you upgrade.
(TP) you can do this entire upgrade procedure without downtime etc.

(TP) There are a couple of things you might want to apply before doing this:

* Flushing all your indices might be a good idea
* Prevent shards from being relocated or allocated on other nodes while nodes are going down during the upgrade
   * `cluster.routing.allocation.disable_new_allocation = true`
   * `cluster.routing.allocation.disable_allocation = true`
   * also set `cluster.routing.allocation.cluster_concurrent_rebalance`  and ``cluster.routing.allocation.node_concurrent_recoveries` to a low number to prevent your cluster to go nuts when you allow allocation again.

(TP) (see http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/reference/modules/cluster.html for detail)
   * along the same lines it might make sense to throttle recoveries and merges for stability and preventing your segments from diverging too much (http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/reference/index-modules/store.html

* now you can start upgrading nodes.
(TP) you might also want to look into this gist from clinton https://gist.github.com/clintongormley/3888120 that shows a technique that can be used to upgrade.
(FN) In general I recommend to practice this on a staging system with more than 2 machines etc.
(TP) Another thing I would recommend is to take your time doing this, don't rush, wait after your cluster stabilizes after upgrading a node.

(TP) I can see the problem with backing up stuff but then you can simply run 2 commands:

```
# make all indices read only
curl -XPUT 'localhost:9200/_settings' -d '
{
  "index.blocks.write" : true
}

# flush data to disk and clean transaction logs
curl -XPOST 'http://localhost:9200/_flush'

# optimize to a single segment -- yet I would not recommend this!!

(TP) curl -XPOST 'http://localhost:9200/_optimize'
```

i think this would still work find in a client scrip so we don't need a dedicated API, right?
(TP) I we have more sophisticated backup / restore apis this might change.

(FP) Thank you, @s1monw 
I agree all that could be done with existing API.
(FP) I just notices that the algorithm contained some steps which need to be done every time, so could be wrapped in a single call.
Concerning `optimize`, i remember that "Simon says: optimize is bad for you", but still at some point could be useful for our time-sliced indices.
(TP) i think, we can close this ticket for now.
(TP) probably, this should be skipped until some more use cases come (e.g.
after ES will have nice backup API).
Anyway, thank you for the help and patience :)
(FP) @gakhov I agree if you have time sliced indices which don't change anymore at some point it might totally make sense to call optimize during a quite period.
(TP) Yeah i think there are always use-cases but in general if you have a incrementally changing index optimize is not needed IMO.
I will close this for now!
Hope that helped you to get more clarity along the lines.
simon

(FP) @s1monw this is a good procedure for standard-case upgrades, but this still doesn't account for upgrading to an incompatible version (0.20 to 0.21 for example), where nodes will fail to communicate with one another, and clients compiled against a previous version of ES.jar won't be able to access the cluster.
(FP) Does the only option we have when upgrading to a new major version is creating a new cluster?
If so, could it become an easier upgrade path in the future?
> Does the only option we have when upgrading to a new major version is creating a new cluster?
If so, could it become an easier upgrade path in the future?

(TP) yeah i think at this point you have to gracefully bring your cluster over to a new clustername and once you have the majority of the nodes migrated you bring you clients over and continue with the rest of the machines.
(TP) I don't see how we can get around this with major API incompatibilities at this point but there is lots of room for (IMPROVE)ment here.

title: src/config.c:170: format warning
body:
gcc isn't happy with 780bea6:

```
src/config.c:170:2: warning: format ‘%ld’ expects argument of type ‘long int’,
    but argument 4 has type ‘long long int’ [-Wformat]
```
Really?
Your libc defines `PRId64` as `ld`?
(FP) That makes no sense.
I guess you are building under 32 bits?
No, it's gcc 4.6.1, glibc 2.14 on Linux 3.0 x86_64.
(TP) Can you actually check your `inttypes.h` for the declaration of `PRId64`?

(TP) Under 64-bit Linux, a `long int` is 64-bit, so I guess it makes sense for them to declare it as such (you know, so we're safe when we move to 128-bit processors and a `long long int` becomes 128-bit ;)

```
$ cat /usr/include/inttypes.h
[snip]

/* The ISO C99 standard specifies that these macros must only be
   defined if explicitly requested.

*/
#if !defined __cplusplus || defined __STDC_FORMAT_MACROS

# if __WORDSIZE == 64
#  define __PRI64_PREfix        "l"
#  define __PRIPTR_PREfix       "l"
# else
#  define __PRI64_PREfix        "ll"
#  define __PRIPTR_PREfix
# endif

/* Macros for printing format specifiers.

*/

/* Decimal notation.

*/
# define PRId8          "d"
# define PRId16         "d"
# define PRId32         "d"
# define PRId64         __PRI64_PREfix "d"

[snip]
```
@tanoku, PRIdMAX defined as `ld` on glibc if  __WORDSIZE == 64.
(FP) OK, that makes perfect sense.

(TP) I see two options here: either redefine `PRId64` to be actually `lld`, or change the `long long int` to `int64_t` in the function's signature (together with possibly the name of the methods to `set_int32` and `set_int64`.
(TP) Carlos and I were actually considering renaming the methods to `int32` and `int64`, so I guess changing the types too makes sense...
See #436

title: fix issue with jQuery 1.8.1.
body:
I recently upgraded from jQuery 1.7.2 to 1.8.1 in a Rails app, and noticed this error in my logs:

```
[2012-09-26 01:05:19] ERROR NoMethodError: undefined method `each' for "":String
	/Users/fijabakk/src/git/MiniProfiler/Ruby/lib/mini_profiler/client_timer_struct.rb:40:in `init_from_form_data'
	/Users/fijabakk/src/git/MiniProfiler/Ruby/lib/mini_profiler/profiler.rb:111:in `serve_results'
	/Users/fijabakk/src/git/MiniProfiler/Ruby/lib/mini_profiler/profiler.rb:139:in `serve_html'
	/Users/fijabakk/src/git/MiniProfiler/Ruby/lib/mini_profiler/profiler.rb:195:in `call'
```

The app is using the `use_existing_jquery` setting.
(FPD) It looks like jQuery may be serializing null differently than before (though I haven't tried to track down the exact version that introduced the change).
(TPD) This PR fixes the issue by checking for an empty string in addition to `"null"`.
(TPD) I added the empty value to `spec/fixtures/weird_client_request.yml` so it's caught by the specs.
Thanks for an awesome tool!
(TP) thanks, keep the patches coming
(FP) we should probably clean the js up a bit though, the interface is a bit wonky

title: (REsolve) encoding issues with array-of-hstore columns (fixes bug 11135).
body:
We didn't have enough encoding for the wire protocol to store an array
of hstore types.
So, further encode any hstore that is an array member.

(TPD) Whilst we're here, ensure it's an HashWithIndifferentAccess being
returned, to be consistent with other serialized forms.

(TPD) So now the following migration:

```ruby
  enable_extension "hstore"
  create_table :servers do |t|
    t.string  :name
    t.hstore  :interfaces, array: true
  end
```

produces a model that can used like this, to store an array of hashes:

```ruby
  server = Server.create(name: "server01", interfaces: [
    { name: "bge0", ipv4: "192.0.2.2", state: "up" },
    { name: "de0", state: "disabled", by: "misha" },
    { name: "fe0", state: "up" },
  ])
```

More at http://inopinatus.org/2013/07/12/using-arrays-of-hstore-with-rails-4/

I submit that the single build error was due to a Travis-internal issue:

````
#<ActionDispatch::Session::MemCacheStore:0x00000003897170> is unable to find memcached server.

#<Dalli::RingError: No server available>
````

and it should be run again.

title: using animation by colladaloader
body:
(TPD) Hello world,
in order to get an exported animation from 3ds max - opencollada 
rendered in webgl - three - by using ColladaLoader() 
(from your examplecode webgl_collada.html)
I ran into unexpected behaviour using .dae files see:
http://www.weberforschen.de/cms/fileadmin/js/colladaloader.zip

Usecase1 - demom.dae
Trying a model I found on the net using skin controller and animated bones on about 30 keyframes,
then exporting it by opencollada - 3ds max 2010,
loaded by THREE ColladaLoader() -
Animation is showing fine!

Usecase2 - koi_skin_anim.dae
I tried to rebuild the scene in 3ds max 2010.

(FPD) (structure is slightly more expensive in size)
The scene is rendered fine by THREE.WebGLRenderer() but missing animation.

Debugging the js didnt show me differences in walking through parsing the dae, 
nor getting error messages by exceptions or anything else...

Questions:
- Does anybody see the difference between the two, which prevents U2 from showing animation?
- is there any advise how to build the 3d scene in Max to get animation exported?

(TPD)(BTW I tried to use morpher modifier in Max building morph targets see:
 http://update.multiverse.net/wiki/index.php/creating_Morph_Animations_with_3ds_Max
but using exported dae fails at all)
- why does U1 load fine, despite not using animation by morphtargets?
greets - 6ert
Thanks a lot for sharing the files.
Having files to tests with is always priceless!
I've done some tweaks in the ColladaLoader.

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/commit/81d338e915d569271daaca40b156f46fda96acb5

With the latest version U1 now also show the textures.
U2 shows the geometry and textures but no animation (does it have animation?)
Yes - U1 and U2 have keyframed bones animation.

(TP) Maybe my description wasnt detailed enough:
-  imported U1 from extern source in 3ds max 2010 because of its (IMPROVE)d capabilities.

(TP) -  build my own U2 from scratch keeping the guidelines from U1 (bones, skin modifier, no morph targets)
- 3ds max 2010 shows animations for both of the usecases.

(TP) - U1 and U2 exported by opencollada (same parameters) to .dae

talking about the 'animation' tagged section in .dae, both of the exported usecases are identical in structure.

(I investigated the source of the collada by xml editor)

loading the scenes by ColladaLoader() and rendering by WebGLRenderer()
U1 shows geometry, images, animation
U2 shows geometry, images, no animation

No error messages, no debugging hints to see any differences between the two
@timknip: Any ideas?
(TP) Looking at it... but need add some (temporary) debug code to ColladaLoader to find out what's going sour here.
Will report my findings later.

Big NOTE: 
Current skinning/animation is a ugly hack: the skinned animation now is 'transformed' to a simple bunch of morph-targets.
(TP) That's because at time of writing ColladaLoader three.js only allowed for 2 bones per vertex AND I didn't understand howto implement :-) Anyway: this might also be cause of problem.

(FN) Think the problem is related to how geometry is defined:

A:

```
<geometry>
  <mesh>
    <triangles />
  </mesh>
</geometry>
<geometry>
  <mesh>
    <triangles />
  </mesh>
</geometry>
<geometry>
  <mesh>
    <triangles />
  </mesh>
</geometry>
```

B:

```
<geometry>
  <mesh>
    <triangles />
    <triangles />
    <triangles />
    ...
  </mesh>
</geometry>
```

A works, B doesn't.... investigating further...
(FP) Hmmm... kind of complex to solve.
Will take some time.
(FP) @6ert So: stuff will work with pattern A.
(FN) Not sure how to accomplish it from within MAX, but think its got to do with how the 'skin geometry' is defined (ie: A means 'separate object', whilst B means 'grouped objects').
(FN) Maybe 'exploding' or 'ungrouping' will do the trick.
(FN) Could you experiment a bit, trying to get pattern A instead of B?
(FN) just check the library_geometries element in the COLLADA xml.
(FP) I'll try fix this coming days.

(TP) @timknip
the separated 'skin geometry' actually is a multi/sub object texturematerial assigned to a solid mesh in 3ds max.
removing the material results in an untextured mesh, which is showing animation!

(TP) (so youre right on your assumption)
but maybe the collada parser simply gets confused about the material nodes needing additional subdecisions?
nevertheless - thanks for spending your time...

(FN) @6ert
The problem lies in the skin's "vertex weights" and "joints".
(FN) With the multi/sub texture material assigned some indexing goes sour.
(FN) Anyway: for the moment try to workaround the issue (don't use multi/sub materials).
(TP) The issue is on my TODO, but as said: its kind of hell to fix (albeit possible of course).
(TP) As soon as I find some time I'll fix... keep an eye on this issue.

(TP) solved by @6ert himself here:
https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/746

I guess @timknip will know if it's been fixed in a proper way :)

(FP) Hi, 
I've read all topics of @6ert and his demonstration on his website, but I've still a problem:
I create a very simple animation (with 3DS max 2012, auto-key animation & OpenCollada exporter) here: 
http://www.simoncarre.fr/webGL/ThreeJS/tests/models/test4.dae

But when I load this collada on three.js scene (the monster scene), the skin table is empty so I dont have any animation...
How create or initialize this table or just how animate my .dae object :)

My test file here : http://www.simoncarre.fr/webGL/ThreeJS/tests/test4.php

Thanks !

(FP) several issues:
1.colladaloader in current version doesnt support all kind of animation:
I got errormessages on nodes 'transform' and 'rotation' in your model.
(FP) Im not quite sure on this subject, but my example scene uses bone animation which works for me.

(TP) 2.You are using three.js r46 which is using several patches preventing my fixes to ColladaLoader.js in r45 to work
see my last comment on https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/746
Maybe I find some time to fix ColladaLoader in current version...

(TP) Hi 
I update my work on this link:
http://www.simoncarre.fr/webGL/ThreeJS/tests/test4.php
i think the problem is not with r46 because the monster move without problems.
(FP) It's a problem with my collada file when I work on 3DS max.
I've apply a modifier 'skin' on my teapot et now I've a good skin table on three.js.
(FN) But now, it's a problem with my keyframes on 3DS...
The 'morphTargetInfluences' table is empty, I dont have my differents keyframes.
(FP) Can you say me how create a good object with 3DS ?

(type of modifiers to apply, how use keyframes...)

Thanks for your help :) (and sorry for my bad english...)

on r46:
The monster scene doesnt use MSO (multi sub object) texture.
(TP) On such a model you wont get the problems mentioned above - its just acting fine.
(TP) My patch to three r45 is related to that MSO problem and its based on indexing material morphTargets (see ColladaLoader.js).
(FP) In r46 we got several patches from third site against material indexing, which makes my patch useless.
(FN) So avoid using MSO in your 3dsmax scene and youre on the safe side.

on keyframes:
i gave the model in 3dsmax a skin modifier, which is acting on bones from biped tools.
(FN) using bones in such a context seams to be essential on ColladaLoader.
so I guess what youre doing is to put some 'handmade' skeleton system into your skin, which will not be recognized.

(FN) (Console says on your scene: tranlastion, rotation is no property of object)

conclusion:
try a model without MSO and using skin modifier on biped skeleton
Thanks !
The problem was really on my biped skeleton...
(TP) I have changed that ;)

title: RCpp packages that link to dynamic libraries besides rcpp?
body:
(Specifically, I'm using guitar here as an example, which links to libgit2)

Our [src/makevars](https://github.com/cscheid/guitar/blob/experimental-devtools/src/makevars) has extra bits for the linker to use:

    PKG_LIBS += `$(R_HOME)/bin/Rscript -e "Rcpp:::LdFlags()"` -lgit2

from inside RStudio, using the latest devtools package via install_github, things *almost* work:

    > load_all("/Users/cscheid/code/guitar")
    [ ... lots of compiler output ... ]
    * DONE (guitar)
    Adding files missing in collate: guitar.R
    Error in dyn.load(dllfile) : 
      unable to load shared object '/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so':
      dlopen(/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so, 6): Library not loaded: libgit2.0.dylib
      Referenced from: /Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so
      Reason: image not found    

seems something, somewhere, forgot to load libgit2.

(FPD) Strangely enough, it appears that the compiler line correctly includes -lgit2:

    g++ -arch x86_64 -dynamiclib -Wl,-headerpad_max_install_names -undefined dynamic_lookup -single_module -multiply_defined suppress -L/usr/local/lib -o guitar.so blob.o commit.o entry_points.o guitar.o index.o odb.o odb_object.o oid.o reference.o repository.o tag.o time.o tree.o types.o /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/Rcpp/lib/x86_64/libRcpp.a -lgit2 -F/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/.. -framework R -Wl,-framework -Wl,Corefoundation

Am I doing something stupid like missing the critical bit of documentation?
(TPD) When building guitar using the traditional R64 CMD build and R64 CMD INSTALL workflow, things work correctly.
(FND) There is an [experimental-devtools](https://github.com/cscheid/guitar/tree/experimental-devtools) branch in the guitar repo that has the current version, if you feel like trying it.
(TPD) You'll need to compile libgit2 from github, of course, which has its own challenges :)
I'll let @jjallaire tackle this one.
Thanks for trying it out!
(FP) Ok, sorry, I'm playing with this further, and i think it's stupidity on my part about RStudio.

(TP) I get further if I just do this on a tty R64 session:

    * DONE (guitar)
    Adding files missing in collate: guitar.R
    Error in loadRcppModules() : 
      loadRcppModules can only be used within a .onLoad function

It still doesn't work, but according to https://github.com/hadley/devtools/issues/61, I need to go to Eddelbuettel and plead help :)

The rest of the problem seems to be that I'm failing to let RStudio know about libgit2.0.dylib.
(FN) It currently lives on /usr/local/lib, but even after symlinking it to /usr/lib, or copying the actual library file to /usr/lib/libgit2.0.dylib, RStudio still fails to find it.
(FP) It might not even be *entirely* my fault!

Hi Carlos,

Are you using RStudio Build and Reload or devtools::load_all() to build the package?
If you are using Build and Reload I'd be surprised if there was a variation in behavior because all it does under the hood is call R CMD INSTALL.
(TP) If you are using devtools::load_all I'm not sure what's going on (I'm not aware of anything that would make load_all work different under RStudio visa vi the Terminal or R GUI).

(TP) Note that the 2nd problem related to loading modules should be idiosyncratic to load_all (since the error results from the fact that load_code simulates but don't exactly replicate the behavior of R package loading).
(TP) You should be able to get past this error by using Build and Reload since that will literally reload the package in a fresh R session.
J.J.
I am using devtools::load_all().

From a bash shell:

    $ R64 
    > library(devtools)
    > load_all("/Users/cscheid/code/guitar")
    Loading guitar
    Loading required namespace: Rcpp
    Loading required package: Rcpp
    Adding files missing in collate: guitar.R
    >

From RStudio 0.97.312:

    > library(devtools)
    > load_all("/Users/cscheid/code/guitar")
    Loading guitar
    Loading required namespace: Rcpp
    Loading required package: Rcpp
    Adding files missing in collate: guitar.R
    Error in dyn.load(dllfile) : 
      unable to load shared object '/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so':
      dlopen(/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so, 6): Library not loaded: libgit2.0.dylib
      Referenced from: /Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so
      Reason: image not found

I thought the issue was 32-bit vs 64-bit, but running R from a bash shell gives me a *different* error:

    > library(devtools)
    > load_all("/Users/cscheid/code/guitar")
    Loading guitar
    Loading required namespace: Rcpp
    Loading required package: Rcpp
    Adding files missing in collate: guitar.R
    Error in dyn.load(dllfile) : 
      unable to load shared object '/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so':
      dlopen(/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so, 6): no suitable image found.

Did find:
	/Users/cscheid/code/guitar/src/guitar.so: mach-o, but wrong architecture

(Showing my complete ignorance here, I don't know what you mean by Build and Reload!)

(TP) If you create an RStudio project based on your package's source directory
you'll see all of our package development tools.

(TP) This includes Build and
Reload which unloads the package, builds it using R CMD INSTALL, then
restarts R and reloads the package.

(FN) This takes about 1 or 2 seconds and
preserves all of your IDE state.

(TP) More on package development tools here:

http://www.rstudio.com/ide/docs/packages/overview

Once you've enabled the package development tools then there will also be
global keyboard shortcuts for both load_all and Build and Reload (both of
which automatically save all unsaved source files so you can go from coding
to rebuilt package in one keystroke).

J.J.

Also, I don't think it's *only* architecture mismatch.

(FP) When I do forcefully trigger architecture mismatch problems, (by typing `R CMD INSTALL guitar --no-multiarch` on a bash shell instead of `R64 CMD INSTALL guitar --no-multiarch`) this is what I get instead:

    ** testing if installed package can be loaded
    Error in dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...) : 
      unable to load shared object '/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/i386/guitar.so':
      dlopen(/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/i386/guitar.so, 6): Symbol not found: _git_index_free
      Referenced from: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/i386/guitar.so
      Expected in: flat namespace
     in /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/i386/guitar.so
    Error: loading failed
    Execution halted
    ERROR: loading failed

Notice this is not the same error as the one I get from RStudio (which I reproduce below:)

    ** testing if installed package can be loaded
    Error in dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...) : 
      unable to load shared object '/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/x86_64/guitar.so':
      dlopen(/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/x86_64/guitar.so, 6): Library not loaded: libgit2.0.dylib
      Referenced from: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/2.15/Resources/library/guitar/libs/x86_64/guitar.so
      Reason: image not found

Is there a better forum for me to move this to?

(FN) Carlos,

I discovered the source of the problem -- as of about a month ago we
started setting the DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH to dynamically bind to
different versions of libR.dylib  (e.g.
MacPorts or homebrew).

(TP) Previously
we were setting DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH however this caused conficts over gcc
versions since R64 has it's own version of libgcc_s.1.dylib in it's lib
directory.

(TP) What I didn't know about DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH (and just discovered
today) is that it has an implicit default value (/usr/local/lib:/usr/lib)
which you need to explicitly included when overriding it.

(FN) As a result of
not doing this, we couldn't load any libraries from /usr/local/lib at all!
(TP) (so just doing library(guitar) on a correctly built version also failed).

(FP) Obviously a very serious issue which I'm going to put out a patch release
for later today.

Thanks for your help sorting this out -- will let you know when the new
release is available for download!

J.J.

title: support for proxy repos
body: our builds-for-deploy always take place on a build machine without internet access.
(FPD) instead of a set of maven repos, only one is listed: an internal "proxy" repo, running artifactory.
currently, we have to use a bunch of boilerplate in both plugins.sbt and our "sbt-package-dist" plugin to allow replacing the default repo list with a proxy repo in this case.
(TPD) it would be great if sbt natively supported proxy repos.
something from the environment -- an environment variable or property or something -- would tell sbt that a proxy repo should replace any repo list.
we use environment variable "SBT_PROXY_REPO".

(TPD) the implementation of this feature is most glaring in plugins.sbt, which has to be copied around from project to project as boilerplate, so even if this feature was only implemented for plugin resolution, that would still be a win.
Yes, the idea sounds good to me.
System property and/or environment variable are fine.
It's not quite good enough to have one proxy.
(TP) If you're proxying both Ivy + Maven, you need to set up the same URL as both a maven repo and an ivy repo.
(TP) This is, of course, only possible using Artifactory, since Nexus can't handle proxying non-maven repos AFAICT.
ah, yeah, we're using artifactory.
(FN) maybe the ivy one should be called SBT_PROXY_REPO_IVY?
(TP) (YOU COULD) set them both to the same url if you use artifactory.
(TP) (it would simplify things a lot if sbt published in maven-style, instead of ivy-style.
it's the last project i know of that's still fighting this battle.
(FP) ... i'm no lover of maven, but i think the war was lost a while ago.)
(FP) I just use the same URL with ivy-style paths and again as a maven repo.
(TP) It's two (REsolve)rs, but one repo.
(TP) I also hook it into sbt.boot.properties so all SBT (REsolve)s that way.
(TP) fixed by #472

title: Only output Server logs in Development
body: Right now when you start a server via `rails s`, the logger gets extended so that it logs to the file system and also to stdout.
This extension behavior is not "intelligent" and if the default logger is already set to output to stdout, then the contents will be received twice.
To capture logs in accordance with http://www.12factor.net/logs some platforms require the logs to be sent to standard out.
(FPD) If a logger is set to stdout, and the server is started using `rails server` instead of another method (i.e.
`thin start` etc.)
then the app will produce double logs.
(TPD) This PR fixes the issue by only extending the logger to standard out in the development environment.

(FND) So that in production you don't get double logs like this: ``` ActionView::Template::Error (wrong number of arguments (5 for 4)): 1: <% lang_index = 0 %> 2:
3:
    4: <% repos.group_by(&:language).each do |lang, repos| %> 5: <% unless lang == nil %> 6:
  • " data-toggle="tab"><%= lang %>
    • 7: <% end -%> app/views/shared/_repos.html.erb:4:in `_app_views_shared__repos_html_erb___1685450633638247395_70300668607000' app/views/pages/index.html.erb:13:in `_app_views_pages_index_html_erb__2084723628308867770_70300687584880' ActionView::Template::Error (wrong number of arguments (5 for 4)): 1: <% lang_index = 0 %> 2:
    3:
      4: <% repos.group_by(&:language).each do |lang, repos| %> 5: <% unless lang == nil %> 6:
    • " data-toggle="tab"><%= lang %>
      • 7: <% end -%> app/views/shared/_repos.html.erb:4:in `_app_views_shared__repos_html_erb___1685450633638247395_70300668607000' app/views/pages/index.html.erb:13:in `_app_views_pages_index_html_erb__2084723628308867770_70300687584880' ``` ATP Railties.
Opened against master in favor of #10999
1 week ping cc @drogus

I'm assigning to myself for review

@schneems I'll ping you later to rebase this after of my review :)
(FP) This make sense.
@schneems please rebase this.
Thanks!!
(TP) changelog rebase dance done and pushed.
Thanks!!

(TP) While this does solve the problem in non-development environments, the problem still exists in development, so it does not fix issues #10977 or #11415 which were both closed and redirected to this issue.
(TP) I like to disable development logging to files since all the do is fill up my filesystem and I watch STDOUT anyway.
(FP) There still doesn't seem to be a way to disable file logging while maintaining correct logging in non-server processes.

title: [Routing] fix handling of slashes and whitespace in pattern/prefix
body:
(TPD) BC break: no
feature addition: no

The first commit fixes the handling of two starting slashes in the pattern.
It would be confused with a network path e.g.
`//domain/path` when generating a path, so should be prevented.
(TPD) The second commit fixes the handling of whitespace in RouteCollection::addPrefix.
It wasn't trimmed there but it is trimmed in Route::setPattern.
So it can be out-of-synch between RouteCollection::getPrefix <-> Route::getPattern.
Empty

title: Reduce the number of items in the action bar when using tab navigation
body: Currently the items in the action bar take up too much space when using tab navigation.
Landscape is ok, but in portrait the tabs become to small.
(FND) This commit reduces the available spaces to 1 while using tab navigation in portrait.
I am incredibly torn on things like this.
(TP) I definitely agree that tabs and action items in portrait are a crowded affair.
(TP) however, I'm hesitant to hard-code a limit the action items to only one when in tab navigation mode.
I do like the idea of limiting how many items can be displayed (to an extent).
(TP) I also think that perhaps this is on the responsibility of the implementer on limiting how many items they add, knowing what navigation type they are currently using.
(FN) Using a `menu` and `menu-v11` version of their XML or setting the `showAsAction` value programmatically by checking `Build.VERSION.SDK_INT` allows this manual control with fairly minimal effort.
(FP) I'm going to be doing a lot of work with the action item inflation tomorrow so let me think on it a bit.
(TP) Relying on `menu` and `menu-v11` is not enough to get the desired results, you would also have to include qualifiers for `port` and `land`, which is far to much duplication in my option.
(TP) Doing this in code at inflation is also too much because you have the same checks in every file, not very DRY.
(TP) I understand not wanting to hard code the limit, because sometimes it doesn't apply and the user may want two items instead of one.
(TP) So instead of a hard coded limit, what if that limit was exposed via a setter method?
(FN) Something like `setMaxActionItemsPort(int max)` and `setMaxActionItemsLand(int max)`.
At least this way there is some flexibility and it can be used regardless of navigation mode.

title: ActiveRecord should provide a convenient way for a model object to exclude itself from a scope
body: (TPD) in addition to handling an exception thrown when uniqueness is validated upon saving a record, I often find it necessary to check whether a given record has some unique attribute when no writing to the database is necessary.

(TPD) The code usually looks something like this:

    class MyModel < ActiveRecord::Base
      def  all_other_records_in_some_class_method_or_scope
        return self.class.some_class_method_or_scope if self.new_record?
self.class.with_scope(self.class.where('id != ?

', self.id)) do
          self.class.some_class_method_or_scope
        end
      end
    end

(The reason for the early return when `new_record?
== true` is that self.id doesn't usually behave nicely for unsaved records.)

ActiveRecord::Base could encapsulate this logic so that this code would be reduced to the following:

    class ActiveRecord::Base
      def  all_other_records_in scope
        return self.class.__send__(scope) if self.new_record?
self.class.with_scope(self.class.where('id != ?

(TPD) ', self.id)) do
          self.class.__send__(scope)
        end
      end
    end
    class MyModel < ActiveRecord::Base
      def  all_other_records_in_some_class_method_or_scope
        all_other_records_in :some_class_method_or_scope
      end
    end

Note that the scope argument need not be a scope.
(FND) Any class method with any return type should be valid.
(TPD) I submit this feature to the Rails team because I strongly suspect my implementation is far from optimal but don't know my way around ActiveRecord well enough to know of a better solution.
Please send your feature request to the Rails Core mailing list, or try to propose it in a pull request, to gather more people discussing about it.
(TP) Lets keep the issues tracker for issues ;).
Thanks!

(TP) Sorry, didn't realize I could start with a PR without creating an issue to
track it against first.

On Fri, Nov 23, 2012 at 5:31 AM, Carlos Antonio da Silva <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Please send your feature request to the Rails Core mailing list, or try to
> propose it in a pull request, to gather more people discussing about it.
> Lets keep the issues tracker for issues ;).
Thanks!

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/8297#issuecomment-10655642>.
@betesh no problem.

(FN) The best ways to initiate a discussion about a new feature is to either try the rails core mailing list to get some feedback first, or go straight to the code and put up a pull request showing your intents.
(FN) When in doubt, the core list + some code examples is the best to start with.

title: In JS client, Group names are not encoded in the querystring when a transport reconnects
body: e.g.

(TP) if add connection to group "group++1", 
Groups.Add(Context.ConnectionId, "group++1");

Then groups in the request querystring is something like "groups=%5B%22MyHub.group++1%22%5D"

Note the special characters "++" are not encoded, so the group name actually becomes "group  1" in this case.
(FN) The special character "+" in querystring should be encoded like %2B.
(FN) This will affect the streaming transports on reconnect and long polling on every single message.
Can we see if this repros in the .NET client?
(TP) just looks like a simple case of not building the querystring correctly.
in.Net client,  group names are encoded in the querystring, not repro
The .NET client rocks :smile:
lol
(TP) Can you post specific reproduction steps?

I've done the following tests to try and reproduce on my end but the + symbols are always encoded (with & without reconnect):
1.

Raw Sample -> Join group++1 -> Force reconnect
2.
Chat Sample -> Join group++1 -> Force reconnect

(TP) Looks like we may need to use encodeURIComponent() instead of escape(), see http://xkr.us/articles/javascript/encode-compare/

JSFiddle: http://jsfiddle.net/DamianEdwards/BX6K4/1/
(FP) Aw, I just noticed that the network monitor in Chrome encodes it automatically for me, hence why I wasn't seeing it reproduced.

title: Altered DDBv2's ``batch_write`` to work with ``UnprocessedItems``.
body: (FPD) Per #1679 & #1566, DDBv2 currently just drops ``UnprocessedItems`` (search on page for http://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/API_BatchWriteItem.html) on the floor.
AFAIK, this only happens when the data is valid/retryable, but the throughput has been exceeded.
(TPD) The solution is simply to enqueue them then process through once all the other records are done.
Reviews would be appreciated @danielgtaylor @jamesls @garnaat.

title: [BrowserKit] fixed detection of secure cookies received over https
body:
| yes
| New feature?

| no
| BC breaks?

| no
| Deprecations?

| no
| Tests pass?

(TPD) | yes
| fixed tickets | #7666
| License       | MIT
| Doc PR        | N/A

As reported in symfony/symfony#7666, BrowserKit's cookie handling only recognises a secure cookie if the cookie option is set and the cookie was set over an https request.
The client was not passing the url into the cookiejar update code, causing Cookie::isSecure() to always return false for every cookie.
(TPD) I have corrected this behaviour and added an additional unit test to prove the bug and fix.
This is an updated version of #7668, now rebased and targeted to 2.1 as requested by @Tobion

Sorry, it looks like this is now causing a failed test in the [SessionTest](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/2.1/src/Symfony/Bundle/FrameworkBundle/Tests/Functional/SessionTest.php#L57) - I'm not sure yet if that's to do with the test case or some untested regression I've introduced to BrowserKit.
I'll take a look later today.
(FN) The tests now pass - the scrutinizer failure is to do with there being two classes in the ClientTest file which is as per the original code.

(TP) [SessionTest](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/2.1/src/Symfony/Bundle/FrameworkBundle/Tests/Functional/SessionTest.php#L57) was failing because BrowserKit was incorrectly dropping the `path=/` part of the session cookie set on the first request to `/session_setflash/Hello%20world.` and scoping the session cookie to the `/session_setflash` path - causing the session to be dropped on the request to `/session_showflash`.

(TP) This is because the cookie is converted to a string during [CookieJar::updateFromSetCookie](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/2.1/src/Symfony/Component/BrowserKit/CookieJar.php#L102) and then back into a cookie.

(TP) [Cookie::__toString](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/2.1/src/Symfony/Component/BrowserKit/Cookie.php#L98) was treating `path=/` as equivalent to an empty path since symfony/symfony@1284681 by @fabpot - but i think this is only valid if the cookie was set at the root of the domain.
(TP) I have reverted his commit which has fixed the failing SessionTest and does not appear to have caused any other regressions.

(TP) This seemed to be the correct appraoch, but there's not much context to the previous commit so I'm not sure if @fabpot was just tidying up or if he was fixing an issue that is not covered by tests.
(FP) Let me know if I can do any more to get this issue (REsolve)d.
(TP) fixed in favor of #7738.
(TP) I've cherry-picked your first commit and fixed the failing test a little differently.
Great, thanks for that @fabpot

title: update to jsr166e, renaming spliterator() in ConcurrentHashMapV8 to avoid compile error on Java 8
body: Hi Elasticsearch team, while playing with ES build on Java 8 I encountered this issue, a name clash of JDK 8 spliterator() method in java.util.Set and jsr166e ConcurrentHashMapV8 spliterator().
I updated to the latest CVS of jsr166e but the issue did not disappear.
So I simply renamed the method to spliteratorV7().
(TPD) This should allow compilation unless this is fixed in upstream jsr66e.

body:
| yes
