| no
| BC breaks?

| no
| Deprecations?

| no
| Tests pass?

(TPD) | yes
| fixed tickets | -
| License       | MIT
| Doc PR        | -

This updates the UPDGRADE-2.2.md with missing information.
This is explained in https://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/6738/files#diff-0

(TP) ok. the change made problems for me when i upgraded from 2.1 to the current master so i thought other people would also want to be notified for 2.2. but maybe the cmf routing is indeed the only thing using core routing in a way that actually makes a difference.
(we had a name collision on getPath and overwrite get/setPattern)
(FP) Well, there is some confusing about this because it is added in an UPGRADE-3.0.md file.
(TP) It looks like it is important for 3.0 (which does not exists yet :)), but actualy it is important for 2.2, i think?
(TP) The thing is that you can update this when upgrading to 2.2 but you can also wait until 3.0, your choice.
But they are deprecated in 2.2, aren't they?
So we should get a 'deprecation' message if we use the old names?
(FP) > Related, should we upgrade the docs for this change, or should we wait until 3.0?
No, that's the big difference.
(TP) There is no deprecation message as it will be supported for all versions of Symfony 2.
@WouterJ though there is a `@deprecated` annotation on the Route::getPattern method.
the doc is already updated for 2.2. new projects at least should use the new way.
@fabpot and @dbu thank you, I understand it now.

title: new_user_session duplicated on routes
body: (FPD) I'm trying to set a custom route to sign_in, but, when I try to override the new_user_session, I got a duplicate new_user_session.

routes.rb
```
devise_for :usuarios do
  get '/cadastro', :to => "devise/registrations#new", :as => :new_usuario_registration
  get '/entrar', :to => "devise/sessions#new", :as => :new_usuario_session
  post '/entrar', :to => "devise/sessions#create", :as => :usuario_session
end
```

when I run rake routes:

```
new_usuario_registration    GET      /cadastro(.

:format)               {:controller=>"devise/registrations", :action=>"new"}
new_usuario_session         GET      /entrar(.

:format)                 {:controller=>"devise/sessions", :action=>"new"}
usuario_session             POST     /entrar(.

:format)                 {:controller=>"devise/sessions", :action=>"create"}
new_usuario_session         GET      /usuarios/sign_in(.
: usuario is my User model.
Sry for bad english...
This is a Rails bug, please report to their issues tracker?
Thanks.

title: Tweaked AkkaProtocolStressSpec drop policies
body: (FPD) Basically the probability of dropping the last batches of messages was higher than I expected, since I forgot that I have set the retry limit to 3 on _both_ systems, and not just one.

(FPD) since the expected number of attempts for successful association is ~2.78 this was sometimes triggered on both sides to drop messages too often because of the retry limit of 3 (plus there is a 30% drop probability in both directions already).
Now only one of the systems has an aggressive dropping policy, making the test more reliable.
(FPD) NB: The SystemMessageDelivery* tests are not affected, since they resend messages, while this test just fire-and-forget.
LGTM
LGTM

title: [Rebase #2771] SI-7694 @uncheckedBounds, an opt-out from type bounds checking
body:
[Rebase of #2771]

Synthetic defs introduced by transforms like named/default arguments,
ANF (in scala-async) often introduce a type tree (the tpt of the temporary)
that are based on the types of expressions.

These types are scrutinized in
RefChecks to check that type parameter bounds are satisfied.

(FPD) however, the type of the expression might be based on slack a LUB that
fails to capture constraints between type parameters.

(FPD) This slackness is noted in `mergePrefixAndArgs`:

	// Martin: I removed this, because incomplete.

(FPD) Not sure there is a
	// good way to fix it.

(FPD) For the moment we just err on the conservative
	// side, i.e.
with a bound that is too high.

The synthesizer can now opt out of bounds by annotating the type as follows:

   val temp: (<expr.tpe> @uncheckedBounds) = expr

This facility is now used in named/default arguments for the temporaries
used for the reciever and arguments.

The annotation is hidden under scala.reflect.internal, rather than in
the more prominent scala.annotation.unchecked, to reflect the intention
that it should only be used in tree transformers.
(FPD) Targetting 2.10.3 as this fix is needed by a customer.

**updatE** 

It occurred to me that we should be robust against running the 2.10.3 compiler with the 2.10.2 library, so I've split this PR into two commits.
More details in their comments.
(FP) LGTM, with the caveat that I'm not sure this'll work for bounds checking of type constructors (those are bound-checked in `typedTypeApply`).
(FP) since we're only really interested in kind-* types, it's probably not important.

title: Repeated deletes increment version numbers
body: (FPD) When deleting an already deleted document (before deletes have been expunged), ES returns a 404 NOT found code, but increments the version number.
Is this correct behaviour?

curl -XPUT 'http://127.0.0.1:9200/test/test/1?pretty=1' 

    # {
    #    "ok" : true,
    #    "_index" : "test",
    #    "_id" : "1",
    #    "_type" : "test",
    #    "_version" : 1
    # }



    curl -XDELETE 'http://127.0.0.1:9200/test/test/1?pretty=1' 

    # {
    #    "ok" : true,
    #    "_index" : "test",
    #    "_id" : "1",
    #    "_type" : "test",
    #    "found" : true,
    #    "_version" : 2
    # }


    curl -XDELETE 'http://127.0.0.1:9200/test/test/1?pretty=1'
    # {
    #   "ok" : true,
    #   "found" : false,
    #   "_index" : "test",
    #   "_type" : "test",
    #   "_id" : "1",
    #   "_version" : 3
    # }
(TP) The version number is also incremented when a document which didn't exist is deleted.
(TP) This behaviour makes sense because we can't be sure of the order in which requests reach the shard.

title: atom_feed wrong number of arguments (1 for 0) rails 3.1.0.rc1
body:
(TPD) Hi there,

I have a strange error with feeds generation like atom or rss xml after an upgrade to rails 3.1.0.rc1 :

```
ActionView::Template::Error (wrong number of arguments (1 for 0)):
    1: atom_feed do |feed|
    2:   feed.title("website name")
    3:  
    4:   for post in @posts
  app/views/posts/index.atom.builder:1:in `_app_views_posts_index_atom_builder___1517323884_2197592720'
  app/controllers/posts_controller.rb:31:in `index'
  app/controllers/posts_controller.rb:21:in `index'
```
I have a basic respond_to in my controller which looks like this :

```ruby
format.atom do
  @posts = Post.published
end
```

The code in my index.atom.builder file works with rails 3.0.7.
Any idea ?

Thx

Regards
(TP) Can you post the entire `index.atom.builder` file, that would be very helpful.

Yes, it is :

```ruby
atom_feed do |feed|
  feed.title("website name")
 
  for post in @posts
    feed.entry(post) do |entry|
      entry.title(post.title)
      entry.content(RedCloth.new(post.content).to_html, :type => 'html')
      entry.updated(post.updated_at.to_s)
      entry.author do |author|
        author.name("author")
      end
    end
  end
end
```
(TP) Nothing seems to be wrong in there, could you please paste the full trace so that we can see where is the error being raised?
(FN) Click on "Full Application Trace", copy the large number of lines in a Gist preferably and link
Have a similiar problem ...

    feed.link(:rel =>'license', :href => 'http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/')

and it worked earlier, now (Rails 3.0.9) it gives "wrong number of arguments (1 for 2)" in this line.
however, it works with a clean new Rails project so I really don't know what's wrong.
Tried with an empty new controller, but same error... maybe a plugin problem.
Full trace: https://gist.github.com/1037930
Same issue, Rails 3.0.9.

(TP) found this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5954198/is-rails-3-1-edge-breaking-xmlmarkupbuilder

I can't believe that this is not reproduced in lots and lots of setups..
(TP) Okay, got this fixed after I rewrote default_url_options in my app.
Disregard that.
I'm closing this.
Reopen if reproducible in 3.1.x.

title: Publish Leaderchanged when first seen, see #3131
body:
(FPD) * The problem in ClusterSingletonManagerChaosSpec was that node 4 doesn't publish
  Leaderchanged, because there is never convergence on node 4 of the new Up
  state for the three new nodes before they are shutdown.

When it becomes
  convergence on node 4 prevConvergedGossip and newGossip have same leader
  (i.e.
(FPD) no change).
(FPD) * Leaderchanged is now published when the new leader is first seen, i.e.

same
  as member events.
(FPD) This makes sense now when leader can't be in Joining state.
LGTM

title: Add Formula for gyp.
body:
(TPD) This is a HEAD only formula, since gyp doesn't seem to have a concept
of releases.
(TP) Currently, the recipe is not fully functional since upstream code does not use realpath to locate pylib.
I have sent a mail to their devel list.

title: Don't use Java serialization for storing state on disk or in Zookeeper
body: (FPD) Java serialization causes problems when things are upgraded and we want to make changes to the stored format.
(FPD) Even if the change is backwards compatible semantically, Java will complain about a version mismatch.
(TPD) instead we should use JSON or clojure serialization.
I am counting 68 files that import `java.io.Serializable`, and 38 files that import `java.io.ObjectInputStream`.
Most of these are actually generated by Thrift, and it looks like Thrift is using the `TCompactProtocol` internally.
(FP) So, to be clear, is the idea to remove every single one of these dependencies, or only the dependencies in some subset of the files other than those generated by Thrift?
And, do you have a particular flavor of serialization in mind?
(FN) [Gson](https://code.google.com/p/google-gson/) serializes to JSON, and has a good reputation, but I don't know the rules for introducing dependencies to storm.

(TP) Having poked around the code quite a lot, it seems like you're talking about the part of `nimbus.clj` that sets up the static state of the topology, and in particular [here](https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/0.7.1/src/clj/backtype/storm/daemon/nimbus.clj#L296), where we seem to be calling making use of the stock Java serialize.
Is this correct?
(TP) If so I'll commence writing a patch.
That, and also anywhere objects are stored in zookeeper.
See cluster.clj.
It looks like storm already uses Kryo extensively.
Do you have any objections to using this library for this purpose?
(TP) Oh, I see now that it might be useful to use JSON or some sort of s-expression as serialization, in order to write DSLs later.
If this is true, do you have a particular JSON library you'd like to use?
(FN) Should stick with the JSON library Storm already uses, json-simple.
(TP) Don't know could you try MSGPACK likely solution for that?
(TP) JSON still waste space from some perspective only if we need readable format for diagnostic.
This is very small amounts of data, so space usage is irrelevant.
(TP) JSON is good because it's simple and is already used (so don't need to add any additional dependencies).
(FP) Sorry it's been a bit crazy at my normal work.

(TP) If we're using JSON-simple, then it seems like there are basically two ways to appraoch the problem:

(1) if the `storm.thrift` is known to be stable, serialization can be implemented *ad hoc* to fit exactly that spec, but if this spec changes you'll have to change the serialization procedures
(2) I could do the harder task of making it automatically pick up on the structure indicated by `storm.thrift`

I'm willing to do either, but if (2) isn't necessary I'd like to avoid the unnecessary legwork.
(TP) actually (2) should be less work.
(FN) If we don't care that much about the cost of instantiating objects, it should suffice to use, *e.g.
(FN) *, reflection to pull the public-facing members out of a given thrift-specified object (something like reflection would be cleaner than parsing `storm.thrift` to get critical members).

(TP) So for example a serialized version of the `struct JavaObject` would probably look something like `{"full_class_name": "CowClass", "args_list": [blah blah blah... ]}"` modulo syntax errors, where `full_class_name` and `args_list` are public-facing members.
(FN) I'm no thrift expert but I'm guessing that as long as we have all the public-facing member objects in the JSON, we should be able to reconstruct it losslessly.
(TP) Unless thrift gets crazy in how the classes are implemented behind the scenes, which doesn't seem likely.
Does this sound acceptable to you?
(TP)For Thrift objects you should just use Thrift serialization.

(TP) Here are the spots that need to be changed:

All Utils/serialize and Utils/deserialize calls in https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/src/clj/backtype/storm/cluster.clj - switch to JSON or to clojure serialization.

I believe most of the data structures stored here are defined at https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/src/clj/backtype/storm/daemon/common.clj#L30

How topology and conf are serialized (topology should use Thrift, conf should use JSON): https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/src/clj/backtype/storm/daemon/nimbus.clj#L297

How supervisor stores stuff on local disk: https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/src/jvm/backtype/storm/utils/LocalState.java

(TP) I don't know thrift at all, so to be clear, `Utils/serialize` makes the standard calls to `ObjectOutputStream` [1] to write the serialized object, which means that (given what you said) when we call this method to serialize the topology in `nimbus.clj`, thrift must be serializing by implementing `Serializable` and overriding the appropriate readers and writers.
Right?
(FP) If that's right, it make a lot more sense.
(FP) I was wondering why you'd use java serialization for thrift stuff ...
(TP) Anyway I'll try to have the patch out this week.
[1] https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/blob/master/src/jvm/backtype/storm/utils/Utils.java#L48
No, Thrift has its own serialization library, using the "TSerializer" and "TDeserializer" classes.

The only reason I was using Java serialization for Thrift stuff was an attempt to use one form of serialization for the daemon stuff for simplicity and consistency – I hadn't anticipated the problems that would cause.

Ok, to recap:

* Switch topology serialization to thrift in nimbus.clj
* Switch all calls to `Utils/serialize` in cluster.clj, as well as the conf serialization in nimbus.clj to use JSON or clojure

Sorry for all the messages I'm kind of a storm noob.
(TP) Yes, that in addition to changing how the supervisor serializes/deserializes (supervisor currently delegates to LocalState for that).
(TP) BTW, can you make sure to send me a contributor agreement?
Instructions here (should only take a few minutes): https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/wiki/Contributing-to-Storm
I've sent the agreement.
(FP) One more question, will the testing already in place for this code be sufficient to cover these changes?
Yes, the tests should be sufficient.
(FP) just an update, everything is done.
There is a design issue though.

(FP) The LocalState/Supervisor serialization either needs to know how to serialize the internals of the state, like the `LS-LOCAL-ASSIGNMENTS` map, or it needs to have things serialized serialized before they're passed in.
(FP) Or we need to rewrite LocalState.

(TP) Currently we're doing the second one and it passes all the tests -- not saying it's not got downsides, but it seemed better from a design perspective baking supervisor's implementation into LocalState.

(TP) If you have preferences about how we should handle this let me know -- I don't know how married the project is to the current implementation, though it doesn't look heavily used and seems like it could stand a rewrite anyway.
(TP) (otherWISE) I'll issue the pull request.
(TP) Yea, unfortunately the LocalState is the most important one to fix.
(TP) i think a simple thing to do would be to make the serialization used pluggable – have the constructor for LocalState take in the implementation of some serialization interface.
(TP) Then the supervisor can tune that to its needs.
Oh my god, I thought I shipped this.
My bad.
Let's finish it.
(TP) Having the `LocalState` constructor take in some serialization interface works for everything out of the box except the `workerHeartbeat` -- it is written in pure clojure.

(TP) I'm don't know that much about Clojure, and am not experienced enough in Storm to be comfortable making the call on my own, so here are what i think your options are:

* Write the serializer in clojure.

(FN) lein compiles all Java before clojure code though, so we will have to add a hook so that lein compiles the LocalState serializer before it compiles the Java code in order to avoid the "I can't find that" compiler error.
(FN) * Rewrite LocalState in clojure, and then write the serializer in clojure.
Not an expert on the project but this looks doable.
(TP) Everything using LocalState seems to be in clojure code, unless there's some reflection stuff I'm missing.
(FN) * Rewrite `workerHeartbeat` in Java.
(FN) * Use some sort of deep magic to access `workerHeartbeat` in Java.
There shouldn't be any issues with compilation.
(TP) just make the serialization interface be a Java interface and then implement that serializer in Clojure (using "reify")
(TP) And you should be able to just use pr-str and read-string for the serialization/deserialization in the clojure code.

title: Issue/4717
body: (TPD) fixes SI-4717.

A lazy val declared inside an anonymous class inside a specialized
context no longer crashes Duplicators.

(TPD)  This crashed the typer when it had to retype its
lazy accessor, because there was no `lazy var it` in `$anon`.

(TPD) Furthermore, the duplicated symbol wasn't being added to the list of
declarations of `$anon`.

(TPD) changes:
1) `invalidate` in Duplicators takes an additional parameter which is
the new owner of the new symbol that has to be duplicated.

(FND) If this parameter
is set to `NoSymbol`, then the new owner is `context.owner`, as before.

(TPD) 2) the newly created lazy val symbol is being added to the list of
declarations of its new owner, provided that the owner is a class.
Review by dragos.

@mention dragos
review by @dragos

title: require 'pathname' to fix 'NameError' exceptions
body: The tests began to fail for me locally recently, with several `NameError` exceptions for `Pathname`, while they were running fine on travis.
(TPD) Adding this directive fixed that.
(TPD) might as well be an issue with my system only, in which case you can close this.
All the tests still pass for me.
What ruby version were you dev-ing against?
(TP) It was working again the next day and works ever since.
No idea to what the cause was.
:confused: :question:
Tests fail for jekyll-1.1.2 currently with the same problem.
(FP) Is it possible to apply this anyway?
@mrueg What Ruby version?

(TP) Using latest ruby candidate, ```ruby 2.0.0p247 (2013-06-27 revision 41674) [x86_64-linux]```

I can confirm that this fixes this issue
(FP) Did Ruby 2.0 change this behaviour?
If I’m using Ruby 1.8.7 (2011-06-30 patchlevel 352) [i686-linux] I still get these 9 errors until I upgrade to Ruby 2.0.0?
Weird.
(FP) Why do you think it'd work for me on `1.9.3-p448` if it fails for you on `< 2.0`?
> might as well be an issue with my system only, in which case you can close this.
@maul-esel My system produces the same 9 exceptions.
(TP) After adding your patch the tests run without errors.
I use a default Ubuntu 12.04 (LTS).
Finished tests in 25.053895s, 11.0562 tests/s, 17.7218 assertions/s.

277 tests, 444 assertions, 0 failures, 0 errors, 0 skips
```
(TP) On a fresh clone of Jekyll, Ruby v1.8.7-p371, all the tests run just fine!
This is crazy weird.

I tested on:

 ruby                            | result
-------------------------------|--------
rvm: `ruby-1.8.7-p374`     | fine
rvm: `ruby-1.9.3-p448`     | bad
rvm: `ruby-2.0.0-p247`     | fine
system: `ruby 1.9.3p194` | bad
Running on Ubuntu 13.04.
(FP) i think I get it.

The issue starts in [/lib/jekyll/generators/pagination.rb#L130](https://github.com/mojombo/jekyll/blob/master/lib/jekyll/generators/pagination.rb#L130):

```ruby
    def self.in_hierarchy(source, page_dir, paginate_path)
      # line 130
      return false if paginate_path == File.dirname(paginate_path)
      # line 131
      return false if paginate_path == Pathname.new(source).parent
      ...
    end
```
My `paginate_path` is `/jekyll/test/source`, but `File.dirname(paginate_path)` returns `/jekyll/test`.
So we go to the next line and try to create a new object `Pathname.new(source)` which raise an exception if no `pathname` is required at the top of the file.
It looks like on some systems `paginate_path` *always* equals `File.dirname(paginate_path)` and Jekyll *never* goes to the line 131 and never try to create a `Pathname` object.
Please correct me if I’m wrong.
Sounds sensible.
(TP) So if that's the case, the `require 'pathname'` **should**¹ actually be there (or in `lib/jekyll.rb`).

***
¹ I had always thought it should be unnecessary and it's some ruby fail.
(TP) Ok then we need to add `require pathname` to `lib/jekyll.rb` under `stdlib`.
Done.
Would you mind linking to the PR/revision?
Never!

(TP) :wink:




Yeah, I need to add something to history for this.
Got distracted.
:heart: thank you!!
Much better now.
Related commit: 454e038fad4f434ae0b9cc340f2a4a490d87ced2

title: Was getting an error "expected selector or at-rule"
body:
(TPD) Hi folks,
i was getting this error "Syntax error: Invalid CSS after "": expected selector or at-rule, was "=roundcorner(!s..."
My compass version was 0.10.6, no SASS installations.
Was using RVM.

(TPD) the source code:
=roundcorner(!size=7px)
    -moz-border-radius= !size

After many tries, uninstalling and changing versions of compass/sass, i found a solution.
(TPD) I didn't have specified the haml version into my Gemfile and bundler had installed the latest version... (3.1.x), probably not compatible with my compass version.

(TPD) I added this line into Gemfile:
gem "haml", "~> 3.0.13"

and run: bundle update haml

After that, all seemed to work fine!
Hope this will help someone.

title: Accessing objects outside of renderPlot()
body: Unless I'm doing something wrong, I can't seem to use objects defined outside of renderPlot().
(TP) This is probably due to a bug in ggplot2.
(TP) See https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/issues/743 If this is the source of the problem, the workaround is to pass `environment = environment()` to `ggplot()`.
(TP) As a general note, it's better to name the columns of the data frame when you use `aes()`, instead of pulling out columns as you've done.

(FN) Something like this:

```
  ggplot(mpgData, aes(x=mpg, y=cyl)) + geom_bar(stat="identity")
```

I believe that doing things this way will also avoid the ggplot2 bug.
(TP) Thanks for the notice: `environment = environment()` (REsolve)d the issue!
(TP) I agree that it is better to name x,y values, I only simplified for the example here.
(TP) Naming them doesn't (REsolve) the issue however, `environment = environment()` is the only way I can see it working at the moment.

title: Journal not rolled when all removes are transactional
body: PersistentQueue.remove only rolls the journal if the queue length = 0, journal size >= max journal size, AND open transactions = 0.
This will never occur if all removes are transactional and rolling will only occur when the journal size > max journal size * journal overflow.
Perhaps a similar check should be performed if the queue length is 0 and nothing is removed?
Or perhaps the journal should be rolled even is there are open transactions?
(TP) Hmm, I just looked at the history for PersistentQueue and apparently you fixed this.
Why is this not part of the most recent build?
Closing.
i haven't made a release in a while -- my bad.
i'll do that soon.

title: phantomjs 1.9 hangs when loading page, 1.8 and earlier are fine
body: (TPD) Using 1.9, it usually just wedges and sits there forever doing nothing, but occasionally it will complete successfully.

(FP) same here

```bash
uname -a
Linux niclas 3.8.11-200.fc18.x86_64 #1 SMP Wed May 1 19:44:27 UTC 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

using 1.9.0 phantomjs just hangs.
(TP) I then installed 1.8.2 and everything works fine.
Further investigation reveals that the problem disappears when using phantomjs 1.9 compiled locally from source.
So perhaps the issue is that the 64-bit linux pre-compiled binary package is broken, rather than a bug in the code.
I can't reproduce this (Linux localhost 3.4.0 #1 SMP Wed May 8 19:57:32 PDT 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux).
Also, try to troubleshoot what happens, e.g.
checking the network traffic (https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/wiki/Troubleshooting).
(TP) OK I have worked out what caused the problem, although the issue still remains that the binary package of 1.9 behaves differently to the same version compiled from source.
The server was sending a 302 Redirect in response to the request for "/".
(TP) This redirect had a corrupt message body (it was marked as "Content-Encoding: gzip" but in fact it was not compressed).
This was obviously a fault server-side, but it should not be fatal as the browser can of course ignore the body of a redirect anyway.
1.9-binary was hanging at this point, 1.8 and 1.9-source coped fine.

title: Sometimes AOF can grow unlimited ?
body: What will happen if someone rely on auto-AOF-rewrite, but redis server often restarts ?

According to this code https://github.com/antirez/redis/blob/unstable/src/redis.c#L946
the restart (in default config) triggered when AOF size > 2*original AOF size.

And original aof size
is picked when server starts (or when AOF rewrite happening)

so if I restart server too often AOF will grow unlimited ?
(TPD) i think there should be option to set max AOF size to trigger rewrite when it's reached.
(TPD)  or, at least, existing behavious should be documented.
p.s.

(FND) note
in modern "cloud" environments it's sometimes common to kill/restart servers when deploy or in case of minor faulure etc
so redis restart can happen often (especially for development and staging environments).
Empty

title: [Validator] Let option values reference values in the object graph
body: (FPD) In #790 and #7444 the need to reference dynamic values in constraint options was discovered.
References can contain any valid property path.

(FPD) XML example:

```xml
<property name="value">
    <constraint name="Range">
        <option name="min" reference="min" />
        <option name="max" reference="max" />
    </constraint>
</property>
```

YAML example:

```yaml
properties:
    value:
        - Range:
            min: @min
```

Attention: This example would be consistent with the DIC YAML syntax for service references, but it would be incompatible for options where values starting with "@" are valid expected values.
Is this a problem?

(TPD) PHP example:

```php
$metadata->addPropertyConstraint('value', new Range(array(
    'min' => new Reference('min'),
    'max' => new Reference('max'),
)));
```

Some implementation hints:

Class `Reference` should be an annotation but *not* inherit from `Constraint` (it is no constraint).
(TPD) It probably needs only a constructor.
(TPD) Additionally, we need a `Reference(REsolve)r` (and `Reference(REsolve)rInterface`, of course) that receives a `PropertyAccessorInterface` in its constructor.
(TPD) It needs only a method `(REsolve)Reference(Reference $reference, ExecutionContextInterface $context)` that returns the value of a reference based on the current state of the execution context.
(TPD) All validators that support references then need the `Reference(REsolve)r` to (REsolve) any `Reference` instances when they find them.
(FP) How would you inject the Reference(REsolve)r ?
(FN) Would the ConstraintValdiatorFactory know it and inject it by doing an instanceof check ?
(FN) Or would you require defining all these valdiators as service ?
(TP) The first option seems better for the standalone usage of the component
That's a possibility.
(TP) Alternatively, we could add `(REsolve)Reference` to `ExecutionContextInterface`.
What do you  think?
(TP) yeah, it may be easier (no need to inject the (REsolve)r in constraint validators)
@danielholmes what is not clear for you?
Can we discuss about that here?
(TP) Do you already read the issue #7444?
For me, it's clear, but I can try to answer your questions.
@marcospassos I hadn't seen #7444 before, yea that's all clear.
(FP) It's more work than I thought it might be.
(FP) It's getting late where I am and my work day is full tomorrow so I probably couldn't do it before feature freeze.
If you or someone else completed this generic ```Reference``` PR then it won't take long to put it in to the comparison validators
This will be postponed to 2.4.
There are too many open questions for finishing this by tomorrow.
@bschussek what are the open questions (except about the YML syntax)?
(FP) I would like to work on that to keep live.
(TP) Adding the `(REsolve)Reference` to `ExecutionContextInterface` it seems become easy.

title: "Error forwarding the new session new session request for webdriver should contain a location header with the session" When using PhantomJS with selenium grid in RemoteWebDriver mode
body:
I start a selenium grid hub with it's default startup command,

    java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.33.0.jar -role hub

And I start up PhantomJS in it's webdriver mode, on the same machine, like,

    phantomjs --webdriver=8080 --webdriver-selenium-grid-hub=http://127.0.0.1:4444

When PhantomJS starts up, I get nothing but "All 'OK'" messages,

    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:10:38.849Z] GhostDriver - Main - running on port 8080
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:10:38.850Z] GhostDriver - Main - registering to Selenium HUB 'http://127.0.0.1:4444' using '127.0.0.1:8080'
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:11:47.164Z] HUB Register - register - Registered with grid hub: http://127.0.0.1:4444/ (ok)

But if I try to use that browser, with

    driver = webdriver.Remote(command_executor='http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub',
                              desired_capabilities=DesiredCapabilities.PHANTOMJS)

Looking at the output from the PhantomJS executable,

    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:17:12.531Z] Session [0c5c9500-197c-11e3-8eed-b3b7a73965aa] - _decorateNewWindow - page.settings: {"XSSAuditingEnabled":false,"javascriptCanCloseWindows":true,"javascriptCanOpenWindows":true,"javascriptEnabled":true,"loadImages":true,"localToRemoteUrlAccessEnabled":false,"userAgent":"Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/534.34 (KHTML, like Gecko) PhantomJS/1.9.2 Safari/534.34","webSecurityEnabled":true}
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:17:12.531Z] Session [0c5c9500-197c-11e3-8eed-b3b7a73965aa] - page.customHeaders:  - {}
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:17:12.531Z] Session [0c5c9500-197c-11e3-8eed-b3b7a73965aa] - CONSTRUCTOR - Desired Capabilities: {"platform":"ANY","javascriptEnabled":true,"browserName":"phantomjs","version":""}
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:17:12.531Z] Session [0c5c9500-197c-11e3-8eed-b3b7a73965aa] - CONSTRUCTOR - Negotiated Capabilities: {"browserName":"phantomjs","version":"1.9.2","driverName":"ghostdriver","driverVersion":"1.0.4","platform":"mac-10.7 (Lion)-32bit","javascriptEnabled":true,"takesScreenshot":true,"handlesAlerts":false,"databaseEnabled":false,"locationContextEnabled":false,"applicationCacheEnabled":false,"browserConnectionEnabled":false,"cssselectorsEnabled":true,"webStorageEnabled":false,"rotatable":false,"acceptSslCerts":false,"nativeEvents":true,"proxy":{"proxyType":"direct"}}
    [INFO  - 2013-09-09T18:17:12.531Z] SessionManagerReqHand - _postNewSessionCommand - New Session created: 0c5c9500-197c-11e3-8eed-b3b7a73965aa

Everything *seems* to be fine, but the code crashes :/  I get a huge error stacktrace, mainly down to,

    selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: u'Error forwarding the new session new session request for webdriver should contain a location header with the session.'

(FPD) And if you check the output of the grid hub,

    INFO: Trying to create a new session on test slot {seleniumProtocol=WebDriver, browserName=phantomjs, maxInstances=1}
    INFO: Available nodes: [host :http://127.0.0.1:8080 time out : 300000]

There also seems to be an issue.
(FPD) It seems like, for whatever reason, the grid hub doesn't get any information back from the PhantomJS executable, even though it *seems* like it is processing things correctly.

For testing, I also have a regular selenium node running, on the same machine, with the command

    java -jar selenium-server-standalone-2.33.0.jar -role node

and if I start up a Firefox RemoteWebDriver session (in Python), with
    
    driver = webdriver.Remote(command_executor='http://127.0.0.1:4444/wd/hub',
                              desired_capabilities=DesiredCapabilities.FIREFOX)

all is fine.
(FPD) It looks like everything is set up correctly, I'm keeping things as 'vanilla' and close to what the docs say as possible, but just can't get over the fence here.

title: Webserver: add access to special:// URLs
body: This adds a new HTTP handler allowing for special:// vfs files.

(TPD) Access works analog to VFS via http://xbmchost:port/special/special://path/to/file
It also adds a shortcut URL /log for quick and easy xbmc.log downloading.

.log and .xml files are passed through a User/Pass stripper before download:
   - username:pass in URIs
   - <pass>pass</pass> in XMLs

I added VS2010 project files, but _did not test_ them.
(FPD) since Xcode stuff is voodoo to me, I kindly ask someone in the know to help there.
(FP) The general implementation looks good and something a lot of people have asked for.
(FP) just a few things to (IMPROVE).
(FP) Aside from easy log access, what do we need this feature for?
(TP) While it does clean up credentials, there may be URLs/paths you just don't want people having access to (private stuff, porn, etc.).
IMO there are still plenty of security and privacy issues at bay here.
(TP) implemented the suggested changes.
(FN) Also added filtering of username in xml tags
Looks much better.
(FP) just a few small things and then the code is good IMO.
(TP) I don't really have a strong opinion on what @t-nelson said because I have nothing to hide in my local network.
Thanks, code looks good now for me.
Looking over the commit order I'm a bit confused.
(FP) Is it just github showing the commits in the wrong order or are they actually in the wrong order?

(FN) Shouldn't it be
1.

(TP) [webserver] add HTTPSpecialHandler
2. register CHTTPSpecialHandler
3. add HTTPSpecialHandler to vcxproj

actually 1 and 2 could be squashed down.
(TP) As you'll have to rebase anyway, it would be nice if (YOU COULD) add a "[win32] in front of the "add HTTPSpecialHandler to vcxproj" commit message to make it more obvious.
(TP) This will also need some xcode monkeying when merged.
(FP) its very possible that I changed the order around while rebasing/squashing the last time.
(FP) Would it really make a difference though?
I did squash those two down as requested and rebased again.
(FP) I'm aware that Xcode stuff is missing, thats why I asked for help with that in the PR description ;)
Thanks.
Will if the commits are in the wrong order, the code won't compile for each commit.
Usually the order wouldn't matter but if you e.g.
(TP) bisect to find a bug and you end up between those commits you can't really check if that revision works because you can't compile it.
understood, didn't think about that.
(TP) @t-nelson From what I can see, there are multiple troubleshooting situations where accessing files (and more than just xbmc.log) could be useful in this case.
(TP) More and more, we have situations where it's not entirely clear where users can look at and check these files (android seems to have a few variations for the userdata folder, for example).
(FN) In that sense, I would say this would be a troubleshooting "mode" for many.
I love the idea of being able to do this, and can see it making a lot of situations easier to troubleshoot.
@wsnipex Forgive me, as I'm not a programmer and am not able to tell from the commits, but I assume there's a way to turn special protocol access on or off?
One that defaults to off?

(TP) I also know everyone cringes at GUI settings additions, but if there is a setting for this, i think it should be in the GUI (if you can't find xbmc.log, then you probably can't find advancedsettings.xml).
@NedScott clearly I'm aware of what it's useful for.
(FP) My concern is whether it's useful enough to risk a gaping hole in security.
My comment was mainly ensure this had been considered.
I don't see a gaping hole.
(TP) you can always enable user/pass for the webserver.
(FP) Also most users, me included don't have anything to hide on their own LAN
Ah so potentionally rendering your router's firewall useless doesn't matter?!
It's your first line of defense...
I don't follow.
What has xbmcs webserver to do with your router?
I believe the security concern is valid.
(TP) This needs a switch, and it needs to be off by default.
which security issues are we talking about exactly?
(FP) If there is more data to be sanitized, I'd be happy to do so, but I won't implement a gui option.
Off the top of my head, addon_data.
Some add-ons store plain text passwords for log-ins in various ways.
The log file itself tells everyone on the network what you're watching and when, which is more a privacy concern than a computer security concern, but still an issue for some users.
(TP) i think this would be a bad idea if there was no way to turn it off.
(TP) you can turn it off, turn off the webserver.
I really do not understand the issue here.

(FN) The webserver can be password protected....

edit: @NedScott plz provide concrete examples
I could provide specific examples of add-ons storing passwords in different ways, but we can't predict them all.
Password protecting the webserver is a valid point, but I'm still unsure why file access can't be disabled separately.
I doubt most people would think to use a password on the webserver, or would be aware of what they are exposing on their local network.
I'm certainly no network expert, so maybe it's nothing to be worried about.

I'll more or less shut up if you enable this only when "enable debugging"
is ticked in GUI settings AND a password is set for HTTP access.

(TP) A dialog
probably would not be a bad idea either.

(TP) Though we should probably have one
stating the security/privacy implications of debug logging in the first
place.
(TP) since depending on "debugging enabled via Gui setting" would defy most of the usefulness, I added a gui setting to enable access to special:// urls
How would it defy the usefulness?

(FN) A non-debug log is useless, so enabling
debug is likely a step that will be required anyway.
(TP) Besides, we don't want more GUI settings.
A GUI setting for this: no way...
(FP) I never enable debugging via Gui setting, only via advancedsettings, because I hate the overlay.
So either "if debug logging is enabled" or a Gui setting for this or always enabled.
(TP) You guys were lamenting about the "huge security risk", so a GUI setting is the correct solution.
(TP) I'm for the enablement by the debug gui setting since it shows that you are running in a non standard mode.
(TP) If we where to accept a GUI setting it would also need to indicate that it's a security risk doing so.
(FN) User would have no idea that it was with the current title of this setting.
(FP) then what do you suggest for the settings text?
again the debug gui setting is useless to me and many users.
(TP) If the issue is just wanting to expose the log to the network, then why not just expose the log and leave it at that?
(TP) Is it a security issue to expose only the (stripped) log?
thats the question here.
(TP) I don't see a security issue in exposing the stripped log(or other files), @t-nelson and others obviously do.
(TP) If log only is agreeable, fine for me, but I do not want it dependent on having debugging enabled via GUI setting.
(TP) This is my only requirement, as it makes my own usecase moot.
(FP) Would it make sense to add it to JSON-RPC instead?
That way we can add it as a special permission?
@topfs2: Where would the security be through JSON-RPC?
We have permissions but we don't do anything with them at the moment.
Furthermore for an average joe user it's much easier to open a browser URL to retrieve the log file from a "remote" machine than having to execute a JSON-RPC request etc.

(TP) Hehe, I meant that then we have it more under control, even if the permissions aren't used yet :)
And an url we could still create with a webinterface, e.g.
http://IP:PORT/logs where that webinterface prettifies the log output from jsonrpc.

title: Using custom Vertex Shader with MeshLambertMaterial?
body: (TPD)  Hi I'm trying to do some kind of a custom shader, but I just want to modify the vertex position and not the material.
(TPD) MeshLambert already have light, texture and everything that I need, but I do modify the vertex do give an organic look do the object.
Someone can give me a direction?
Thanks !
Someone?
(TP) The easiest would be to create custom `ShaderMaterial` that would be like lambert, just adding your custom code to vertex shader.

(TP) Internally, standard materials use exactly the same machinery as ShaderMaterial, so you would just need to copy and paste code from here:

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/renderers/WebGLShaders.js#L1187
Hi @alteredq thanks for responding.
This is what you've refereed to?

(TP) http://www.interactiveuniverse.net/Shaders.js

I'm creating objects from the arrays that are provided in the lambert shader and passing them to a new ShaderMaterial instance.
(TP) Doing that I just get a black material without being affected by point lights.

(TP) Almost there ;)

For features from standard materials to work in `ShaderMaterial` you need also to set material flags (lights, fog, etc):

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/src/materials/ShaderMaterial.js#L40

```javascript
shaderMaterial = new THREE.ShaderMaterial( {

	uniforms: 		uniforms,
	vertexShader:   vertexShader,
	fragmentShader: fragmentShader,
	lights: 		true
	});	
```
(TP) It worked !!!
(FP) Thank you so much, when I finish my work I will share with you guys.
(FP) just one last question @alteredq the purpose of doing that was also using a environment map in the object so I can give it a texture.
(FP) How I'm suppose to implement this kind of feature that MeshLambertMaterial contains?
Hmmm.
(TP) i think it should be enough to set proper uniform (`envMap`) and also you would need to stick somewhere at the top of both vertex and fragment shaders `#define USE_ENVMAP` .

(TP) ```javascript
uniforms[ "envMap" ].texture = myCubeTexture;
```

```javascript
vertexShader= [

"#define USE_ENVMAP",

"varying vec3 vLightWeighting;",

THREE.ShaderChunk[ "map_pars_vertex" ],
THREE.ShaderChunk[ "lightmap_pars_vertex" ],

...
```

```javascript
fragmentShader = [

"#define USE_ENVMAP",

"uniform float opacity;",

...
```
just be aware that if you modify vertex positions in a shader, normals coming from static geometry will not be anymore correct and everything will be still shaded according to old positions.

(TP) It worked :D

You guys are really amazing, and I know that devs love to see what other people do with their tools, I hope I can finish my project soon ( It's my personal portfólio and I'm using websockets to connect users in a space interface with spheres ( each is a different project ) and users navigate through the space and each user is a different dynamic point light that moves across my works.
(TP) The engine is pretty functional now I need to work more on designing the stuff.
Thanks you again !

title: Automatically shrink inbound/outbound buffers
body: At the moment we not shrink the inbound and outbound buffers.
(TPD) This means if a connection idle it will take more space then needed.
(FND) We should think about some "sane" way to auto-shrink them while not affect the performance to much.
(TP) Currently, a user can override `discard*ByteBuffer()` to do that, but it will be great if we can introduce something nice by default.
yeah and this will not handle idle connections.
(FN) I would love to also have it for idle ones.
Move to 4.1.0 for now.. As it is more a nice to have :)
(TP) No needed anymore because of the api revamp

title: makefile.mingw: Use normal boost libraries instead of debug for Windows MinGW
body:
(TP) https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=258618

Using -mt-1_52 instead of -mt-s-1_52 as it can be compiled with the --build-type=minimal boost option saving space and time.
(FN) Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/bc06d51f837717943e9720575196be23335b96d6 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated.
(TP) It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.

(FN) If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
(TP) AFAIK -s is need because we have a static boos library, -d of course seems wrong.

From boost-win32.yml:
``./bjam toolset=gcc target-os=windows threadapi=win32 threading=multi variant=release link=static --user-config=user-config.jam --without-mpi --without-python -sNO_BZIP2=1 -sNO_ZLIB=1 --layout=tagged --build-type=complete $makeOPTS stage``
>AFAIK -s is need because we have a static boos library, -d of course seems wrong.
--build-type=minimal outputs only a single library version with the -s- oppressed - at the advantage of being a little faster.
(TP) It seems the library is identical.

(TP) The cost is less clarity without the -s- tag so I will close this pull request and create a new one with -s-

b2.exe --build-type=minimal --with-chrono --with-filesystem --with-program_options --with-system --with-thread^
 --layout=versioned^
 -sNO_BZIP2=1^
 -sNO_ZLIB=1^
 variant=release^
 toolset=gcc^
 link=static^
 threading=multi^
 target-os=windows^
 threadapi=win32^
 cxxflags="%ADDITIONALCCFLAGS%"^
 cflags="%ADDITIONALCCFLAGS%"^
 stage

title: Ray casting not working
body: (FPD) because c is always empty but I don't see anything being done differently in the ray examples.
(TP) Could you do a [jsfiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/) of it?
http://jsfiddle.net/ttAgp/1/
There is a known bug about non-planar quads, but `CubeGeometry` should be fine.
We should have some helper for `Ray`.

(TP) Whenever issue like this pops up, I can never tell if there is a bug in Ray or just Ray is pointing somewhere to empty space (bear in mind second argument is direction vector, not end point of line starting in origin).
> We should have some helper for Ray.

(TP) Whenever issue like this pops up, I can never tell if there is a bug in Ray or just Ray is pointing somewhere to empty space (bear in mind second argument is direction vector, not end point of line starting in origin).
Indeed.
(TP) Will work on that.
(TP) You need to call `object.updateMatrixWorld()` or `render()` prior to your call to `ray.intersectObjects()`.
(FN) Also, as @alteredq pointed out, the second argument in the Ray constructor must be a direction vector -- of unit length.
@WestLangley well spotted!
(TP) Here's the [fixed jsfiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/ttAgp/2/).
Thanks everyone :)

title: Dropdown menu is closed when middle click is used on Chrome and Safari.

(TPD) works fine on the latest versions of Firefox, Opera and IE.
So this must be a glitch specific to webkit.
(TPD) I've checked the code and it seems `$('body').click(close_menus);` is being fired on webkit while it isn't for the other browsers.
(FPD) No idea how to easily fix this (besides checking if the target is a link and the middle button was pressed).

title: xml_http_request fails in IntegrationTests with 3-1-stable
body: (TPD) Recent regression in 3-1-stable with Ruby 1.8.7 (works in 3.0.9 with either 1.8.7 or 1.9.2; and works in 3-1-stable with 1.9.2).

(TPD) Steps to reproduce:

1) create `test/integration/user_stories_test.rb` with the following content:

```ruby
require 'test_helper'
class ProductIntegrationTest < ActionDispatch::IntegrationTest
  test 'xhr' do
    xml_http_request :post, '/products', :id => 1
  end
end
````

2) Execute the following command:

    rake --trace test:integration

[expected output (1.9.2)](http://intertwingly.net/stories/2011/07/16/xhrint-192.html)
[actual output (1.8.7)](http://intertwingly.net/stories/2011/07/16/xhrint-187.html)
(TP) This is a rack regression I've fixed it here https://github.com/rack/rack/pull/210
(TP) I don't believe that this rails issue should be closed until there is a release of rack that fixes the problem.
(TP) The current state is: rails 3.0 w/ rack 1.3.1 works; rails 3-1-stable w/ rack 1.3.1 does not.
(TP) @rubys yeah I'm talking with the rack guys about this, anyways doesn't hurt to keep it open just in case :)
As a reminder this is related https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/2070  https://github.com/bfolkens/rails/commit/d895104a291571927024066a2b50bbf95744bab5
